   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Roger Federer</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div>

              <tr> 
               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><img alt="Gold medal â first place" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Gold_medal_icon_%28G_initial%29.svg/16px-Gold_medal_icon_%28G_initial%29.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Gold medal â first place" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Gold_medal_icon_%28G_initial%29.svg/24px-Gold_medal_icon_%28G_initial%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Gold_medal_icon_%28G_initial%29.svg/32px-Gold_medal_icon_%28G_initial%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="16" data-file-height="16"></td> 
               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Beijing</a></span></td> 
               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_doubles" title="Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics â Men's doubles">Doubles</a> </td>
              </tr> 
              <tr> 
               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><img alt="Silver medal â second place" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Silver_medal_icon_%28S_initial%29.svg/16px-Silver_medal_icon_%28S_initial%29.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Silver medal â second place" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Silver_medal_icon_%28S_initial%29.svg/24px-Silver_medal_icon_%28S_initial%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Silver_medal_icon_%28S_initial%29.svg/32px-Silver_medal_icon_%28S_initial%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="16" data-file-height="16"></td> 
               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 London</a></span></td> 
               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles" title="Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics â Men's singles">Singles</a> </td>
              </tr>
             </tbody>
            </table> 
           </div>
          </div></th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-weight: lighter; color: #555">Last updated on: 28 October 2019.</td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Roger Federer</b> (<small>German pronunciation: </small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Standard_German" title="Help:IPA/Standard German">[ËrÉdÊÉr ËfeËdÉrÉr]</a></span>; born 8 August 1981) is a Swiss professional <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a> player who is <a href="/wiki/ATP_Rankings#Current_rankings" title="ATP Rankings">ranked</a> world No. 3 in men's singles tennis by the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals" title="Association of Tennis Professionals">Association of Tennis Professionals</a> (ATP).<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> He has won 20 <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> singles titlesâthe most in history by a male playerâand has held the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players" title="List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players">world No. 1</a> spot in the <a href="/wiki/ATP_rankings" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP rankings">ATP rankings</a> for a record total of 310 weeks (including a record 237 consecutive weeks) and was the year-end No. 1 five times, including four consecutive. Federer, who turned professional in 1998, was continuously ranked in the top ten from October 2002 to November 2016. </p>
      <p>Federer has won a record eight <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> titles, six <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a> titles, five <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> titles (all consecutive, a record), and one <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a> title. He is one of eight men to have achieved a <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Career_Grand_Slam" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Career Grand Slam</a>. Federer has reached a record 31 men's singles Grand Slam finals, including 10 consecutively from the <a href="/wiki/2005_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2005 Wimbledon Championships">2005 Wimbledon Championships</a> to the <a href="/wiki/2007_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2007 US Open (tennis)">2007 US Open</a>. Federer has also won a record six <a href="/wiki/ATP_Finals" title="ATP Finals">ATP Finals</a> titles, 28 <a href="/wiki/ATP_Tour_Masters_1000" title="ATP Tour Masters 1000">ATP Tour Masters 1000</a> titles, and a record 23 <a href="/wiki/ATP_Tour_500" title="ATP Tour 500">ATP Tour 500</a> titles. Federer is also the only player after <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Connors" title="Jimmy Connors">Jimmy Connors</a> to have won 100 or more career singles titles, as well as to amass 1,200 wins in the Open Era. </p>
      <p>Federer's all-court game and versatile style of play involve exceptional footwork and shot-making.<sup id="cite_ref-Wallace_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wallace-4">[4]</a></sup> Effective both as a baseliner and a volleyer, his apparent effortlessness and efficient movement on the court have made Federer highly popular among tennis fans. He has received the tour <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Awards#Stefan_Edberg_Sportsmanship_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Awards">Sportsmanship Award</a> 13 times and been named the <a href="/wiki/ATP_Awards" title="ATP Awards">ATP Player of the Year</a> and <a href="/wiki/ITF_World_Champion" class="mw-redirect" title="ITF World Champion">ITF World Champion</a> five times. He has won the <a href="/wiki/Laureus_World_Sports_Award_for_Sportsman_of_the_Year" title="Laureus World Sports Award for Sportsman of the Year">Laureus World Sportsman of the Year</a> award a record five times, including four consecutive awards from 2005 to 2008. He is also the only person to have won the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Overseas_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year" class="mw-redirect" title="BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year">BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year</a> award four times. </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Childhood_and_early_life">Childhood and early life</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer was born in <a href="/wiki/Basel" title="Basel">Basel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-credit-suisse1_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-credit-suisse1-5">[5]</a></sup> His father, Robert Federer, is a Swiss-German from <a href="/wiki/Berneck,_St._Gallen" title="Berneck, St. Gallen">Berneck</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Canton_of_St._Gallen" title="Canton of St. Gallen">Canton of St. Gallen</a>, and his mother, Lynette Federer (nÃ©e Durand), is an <a href="/wiki/Afrikaner_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Afrikaner people">Afrikaner</a> from <a href="/wiki/Kempton_Park,_Gauteng" title="Kempton Park, Gauteng">Kempton Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gauteng" title="Gauteng">Gauteng</a>, in <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>. Federer has one sibling, his older sister, Diana,<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> who is the mother of a set of twins.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Since his mother is South African, he holds both Swiss and South African citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> He grew up in nearby <a href="/wiki/Birsfelden" title="Birsfelden">Birsfelden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riehen" title="Riehen">Riehen</a>, and then <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCnchenstein" title="MÃ¼nchenstein">MÃ¼nchenstein</a>, close to the French and German borders, and he speaks <a href="/wiki/Swiss_German" title="Swiss German">Swiss German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Standard_German" title="Standard German">Standard German</a>, English, and French fluently, as well as functional Italian and Swedish; Swiss German is his native language.<sup id="cite_ref-credit-suisse1_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-credit-suisse1-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-story_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-story-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> Federer served as a <a href="/wiki/Ball_boy#Tennis" title="Ball boy">ball boy</a> at his hometown Basel tournament, the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a>, in 1992 and 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-story_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-story-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg/220px-Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg/330px-Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg/440px-Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="304" data-file-height="193"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Roger_Federer_Signature_2013.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer's signature
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Like all male Swiss citizens, Federer was subject to <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Switzerland" title="Conscription in Switzerland">compulsory military service</a> in the Swiss Armed Forces. However, in 2003 he was ruled "unsuitable" and was subsequently not required to fulfill his military obligation.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Instead, he served in the civil protection force and was required to pay 3% of his taxable income as an alternative.<sup id="cite_ref-army_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-army-14">[14]</a></sup> He grew up supporting <a href="/wiki/FC_Basel" title="FC Basel">FC Basel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Switzerland_national_football_team" title="Switzerland national football team">Swiss national football team</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> Federer also credits his <a href="/wiki/Hand-eye_coordination" class="mw-redirect" title="Hand-eye coordination">hand-eye coordination</a> to the wide range of sports he played as a child, including <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer is married to former <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association" title="Women's Tennis Association">Women's Tennis Association</a> player <a href="/wiki/Mirka_Federer" title="Mirka Federer">Miroslava Federer (nÃ©e Vavrinec)</a>, whom he met while they were both competing for Switzerland at the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2000_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 2000 Summer Olympics">2000 Sydney Olympics</a>. Usually called Mirka, she retired from the tour in 2002 because of a foot injury.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> They were married at Wenkenhof Villa in <a href="/wiki/Riehen" title="Riehen">Riehen</a> near Basel on 11 April 2009, surrounded by a small group of close friends and family.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> In 2009, Mirka gave birth to identical twin girls.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> The Federers had another pair of identical twins in 2014, this time boys.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nicknames">Nicknames</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer is nicknamed the "G.O.A.T." (Greatest Of All Time), the "Federer Express" (shortened to "Fed Express" or "<a href="/wiki/FedEx" title="FedEx">FedEx</a>"),<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nickname_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nickname-24">[24]</a></sup> and the "Swiss Maestro."<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philanthropy_and_outreach">Philanthropy and outreach</span></h3> 
      <p>In 2003, he established the Roger Federer Foundation to help disadvantaged children and to promote their access to education and sport.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since May 2004, citing his close ties with South Africa (his mother is South African) he has been supporting the South Africa-Swiss charity IMBEWU, which helps children better connect to sports as well as social and health awareness. In 2005, Federer visited South Africa to meet the children that had benefited from his support.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Also in 2005, he auctioned his racquet from his <a href="/wiki/2005_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2005 US Open â Men's Singles">US Open championship</a> to aid victims of <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2005_Pacific_Life_Open" title="2005 Pacific Life Open">2005 Pacific Life Open</a> in <a href="/wiki/Indian_Wells,_California" title="Indian Wells, California">Indian Wells</a>, Federer arranged an exhibition involving several top players from the ATP and WTA tour called <a href="/wiki/2011_Australian_Open#Rally_for_Relief" title="2011 Australian Open">Rally for Relief</a>. The proceeds went to the victims of the <a href="/wiki/Tsunami" title="Tsunami">tsunami</a> caused by the <a href="/wiki/2004_Indian_Ocean_earthquake" class="mw-redirect" title="2004 Indian Ocean earthquake">2004 Indian Ocean earthquake</a>. In December 2006, he visited <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>, one of the areas in India most affected by the tsunami.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> He was appointed a <a href="/wiki/Goodwill_Ambassador" class="mw-redirect" title="Goodwill Ambassador">Goodwill Ambassador</a> by <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a> in April 2006 and has appeared in UNICEF public messages to raise public awareness of AIDS.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In response to the <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">2010 Haiti earthquake</a>, Federer arranged a collaboration with fellow top tennis players for a special charity event during the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_Open" title="2010 Australian Open">2010 Australian Open</a> called '<a href="/wiki/Hit_for_Haiti" class="mw-redirect" title="Hit for Haiti">Hit for Haiti</a>', in which proceeds went to Haiti earthquake victims.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> He participated in a follow-up charity exhibition during the <a href="/wiki/2010_Indian_Wells_Masters" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 Indian Wells Masters">2010 Indian Wells Masters</a>, which raised $1<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Nadal vs. Federer "<a href="/wiki/Match_for_Africa" title="Match for Africa">Match for Africa</a>" in 2010 in <a href="/wiki/Zurich" class="mw-redirect" title="Zurich">Zurich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a> raised more than $4<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million for the Roger Federer Foundation and <a href="/wiki/Fundaci%C3%B3n_Rafa_Nadal" class="mw-redirect" title="FundaciÃ³n Rafa Nadal">FundaciÃ³n Rafa Nadal</a>. In January 2011, Federer took part in an exhibition, <a href="/wiki/2011_Australian_Open#Rally_for_Relief" title="2011 Australian Open">Rally for Relief</a>, to raise money for the victims of the <a href="/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Queensland_floods" title="2010â11 Queensland floods">Queensland floods</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> In 2014, the "Match for Africa 2" between Federer and <a href="/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka" title="Stan Wawrinka">Stan Wawrinka</a>, again in Zurich, raised Â£850,000 for education projects in Southern Africa.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>On 24 November 2017, Federer received an honorary doctorate awarded to him by his home university, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Basel" title="University of Basel">University of Basel</a>. He received the title in recognition for his role in increasing the international reputation of Basel and Switzerland, and also his engagement for children in Africa through his charitable foundation.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tennis_career">Tennis career</span></h2> 
      <h3><span id="1993.E2.80.931998:_Junior_years"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1993â1998:_Junior_years">1993â1998: Junior years</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Roger_Federer_junior_years" title="Roger Federer junior years">Roger Federer junior years</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer's main accomplishments as a junior player came at Wimbledon in 1998, where he won both the boys' singles final over <a href="/wiki/Irakli_Labadze" title="Irakli Labadze">Irakli Labadze</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> and in doubles teamed with <a href="/wiki/Olivier_Rochus" title="Olivier Rochus">Olivier Rochus</a>, defeating the team of <a href="/wiki/Micha%C3%ABl_Llodra" title="MichaÃ«l Llodra">MichaÃ«l Llodra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andy_Ram" title="Andy Ram">Andy Ram</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> In addition, Federer reached the US Open Junior final in 1998, losing to <a href="/wiki/David_Nalbandian" title="David Nalbandian">David Nalbandian</a>. He won four ITF junior singles tournaments in his career, including the prestigious Orange Bowl, where he defeated <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Coria" title="Guillermo Coria">Guillermo Coria</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> He ended 1998 with the No. 1 junior world ranking, was awarded ITF junior World Champion, and entered his first tournament as a professional during 1998 in <a href="/wiki/1998_Rado_Open" title="1998 Rado Open">Gstaad</a>, where he lost to <a href="/wiki/Lucas_Arnold_Ker" title="Lucas Arnold Ker">Lucas Arnold Ker</a> in the first round.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="1998.E2.80.932002:_Early_professional_career"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1998â2002:_Early_professional_career">1998â2002: Early professional career</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Roger_Federer%27s_early_career" title="Roger Federer's early career">Roger Federer's early career</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer entered the top 100 ranking for the first time on 20 September 1999 and started at the <a href="/wiki/1999_Open_13_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="1999 Open 13 â Singles">1999 Marseille Open</a> defeating the reigning champion of the <a href="/wiki/1998_French_Open" title="1998 French Open">1998 French Open</a>, Spaniard <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Moy%C3%A1" title="Carlos MoyÃ¡">Carlos MoyÃ¡</a>. His first final came at the <a href="/wiki/2000_Open_13" title="2000 Open 13">Marseille Open</a> in 2000, where he lost to fellow Swiss <a href="/wiki/Marc_Rosset" title="Marc Rosset">Marc Rosset</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2000_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2000-46">[46]</a></sup> Federer won the <a href="/wiki/2001_Hopman_Cup" title="2001 Hopman Cup">2001 Hopman Cup</a> representing Switzerland, along with world No. 1 <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The duo defeated the American pair of <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jan-Michael_Gambill" title="Jan-Michael Gambill">Jan-Michael Gambill</a> in the finals. Federer later said that his experience with Hingis "definitely helped me to become the player I am today."<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer's first singles win was at the <a href="/wiki/2001_Milan_Indoor" title="2001 Milan Indoor">2001 Milan Indoor</a> tournament, where he defeated <a href="/wiki/Julien_Boutter" title="Julien Boutter">Julien Boutter</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2000_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2000-46">[46]</a></sup> Although he won his first title already in 1999 on the Challenger tour, winning the doubles event in Segovia, Spain with Dutchman <a href="/wiki/Sander_Groen" title="Sander Groen">Sander Groen</a>, the final was played on Federer's 18th birthday. In 2001, Federer made his first Grand Slam quarterfinal at the French Open, losing to former world No. 2 and eventual finalist <a href="/wiki/Alex_Corretja" class="mw-redirect" title="Alex Corretja">Alex Corretja</a>. His run to the French quarterfinals launched him into the top 15 for the first time in his career.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2001_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2001-51">[51]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>His international breakthrough came at the <a href="/wiki/2001_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2001 Wimbledon Championships">2001 Wimbledon Championships</a>, where the 19-year-old Federer faced the four-time defending champion and all-time Grand Slam leader <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a>. Federer beat the No. 1 seed in a five-set match to reach the quarterfinals.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> In the quarters he faced Englishman <a href="/wiki/Tim_Henman" title="Tim Henman">Tim Henman</a>, eventually losing in a fourth-set tiebreaker.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The first final he reached at the <a href="/wiki/Masters_1000" class="mw-redirect" title="Masters 1000">Masters</a> level came at the 2002 Miami Masters event, where he lost to former and future No. 1 <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a> on hard court.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2002_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2002-53">[53]</a></sup> Federer won his first Master Series event at the <a href="/wiki/2002_Hamburg_Masters" title="2002 Hamburg Masters">2002 Hamburg Masters</a> on clay, over <a href="/wiki/Marat_Safin" title="Marat Safin">Marat Safin</a>; the victory put him in top 10 for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2002_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2002-53">[53]</a></sup> Federer made 10 singles finals between 1998 and 2002, of which he won four and lost six.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2000_46-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2000-46">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RF2002_53-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2002-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RF2001_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2001-51">[51]</a></sup> He also made six finals in doubles. He finished 2001 with an ATP ranking of No. 13, and 2002 was the first year he was ranked within the top 10, finishing at No. 6.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2003:_Grand_Slam_breakthrough_at_Wimbledon">2003: Grand Slam breakthrough at Wimbledon</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2003_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2003 Roger Federer tennis season">2003 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2003, Federer won his first Grand Slam singles title at <a href="/wiki/2003_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2003 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, beating <a href="/wiki/Andy_Roddick" title="Andy Roddick">Andy Roddick</a> in the semifinals and <a href="/wiki/Mark_Philippoussis" title="Mark Philippoussis">Mark Philippoussis</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2003_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2003-56">[56]</a></sup> In August he had a chance to take over the No. 1 ranking for the first time from <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a> if he made it to the Montreal final. However, he fell in the semifinals to Roddick, in a final-set tiebreaker, leaving him 120 points behind Agassi.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-2">[2]</a></sup> This, coupled with early losses to <a href="/wiki/David_Nalbandian" title="David Nalbandian">David Nalbandian</a> at Cincinnati and the US Open, denied Federer the chance to become No. 1 for the duration of the season.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer won his first and to date only doubles Masters Series 1000 event in Miami with Max Mirnyi<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> and made it to one singles Masters Series 1000 event in Rome on clay, which he lost.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2003_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2003-56">[56]</a></sup> Federer made it to nine finals on the ATP Tour and won seven of them, including the 500 series events at Dubai and Vienna.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2003_56-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2003-56">[56]</a></sup> Lastly, Federer won the year-end championships over Andre Agassi, finishing the year as world No. 2, narrowly behind Andy Roddick by only 160 points.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2003_56-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2003-56">[56]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2004:_Imposing_dominance">2004: Imposing dominance</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Federer2004USO.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Federer2004USO.jpg/220px-Federer2004USO.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Federer2004USO.jpg/330px-Federer2004USO.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/12/Federer2004USO.jpg 2x" data-file-width="436" data-file-height="247"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Federer2004USO.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer at the 2004 US Open, where he became the first man since 1988 to win three majors in a season
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2004_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2004 Roger Federer tennis season">2004 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>During 2004, Federer won three Grand Slam singles titles for the first time in his career and became the first person to do so since <a href="/wiki/Mats_Wilander" title="Mats Wilander">Mats Wilander</a> in 1988. His first major hard-court title came at the <a href="/wiki/2004_Australian_Open" title="2004 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> over <a href="/wiki/Marat_Safin" title="Marat Safin">Marat Safin</a>, thereby becoming the world No. 1 for the first time. He then won his <a href="/wiki/2004_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2004 Wimbledon Championships">second Wimbledon crown</a> over <a href="/wiki/Andy_Roddick" title="Andy Roddick">Andy Roddick</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2004_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2004-58">[58]</a></sup> Federer defeated the <a href="/wiki/2001_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2001 US Open (tennis)">2001 US Open</a> champion, <a href="/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt" title="Lleyton Hewitt">Lleyton Hewitt</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> for his first title there.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2004_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2004-58">[58]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer won three ATP Masters Series 1000 events, one was on clay in Hamburg, and the other two were on hard surfaces at Indian Wells and in Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2004_58-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2004-58">[58]</a></sup> Federer took the ATP 500 series event at Dubai and wrapped up the year by winning the year-end championships for the second time.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2004_58-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2004-58">[58]</a></sup> He also won his first tournament on home soil by capturing the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Open_(tennis)" title="Swiss Open (tennis)">Swiss Open</a> in Gstaad. His 11 singles titles were the most of any player in two decades, and his record of 74â6 was the best since <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Lendl" title="Ivan Lendl">Ivan Lendl</a> in 1986. He reached the year-end No. 1 ranking for the first time.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2005:_Consolidating_dominance">2005: Consolidating dominance</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2005_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2005 Roger Federer tennis season">2005 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2005, Federer failed to reach the finals of the first two Grand Slam tournaments, losing the Australian Open semifinal to eventual champion Safin after holding match points, and the French Open semifinal to eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2005_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2005-59">[59]</a></sup> However, Federer quickly reestablished his dominance on grass, winning the <a href="/wiki/2005_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2005 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon Championships</a> over <a href="/wiki/Andy_Roddick" title="Andy Roddick">Andy Roddick</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/2005_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2005 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, Federer defeated <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a> in the latter's last major final.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2005_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2005-59">[59]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer also took four ATP Masters Series 1000 wins: Indian Wells, Miami and Cincinnati on hard court, and Hamburg on clay.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2005_59-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2005-59">[59]</a></sup> The win in Miami was particularly noteworthy as it was the first final contested between Federer and Nadal. Federer recovered from two sets and a break down to take the final in five sets. Furthermore, Federer won two ATP 500 series events at Rotterdam and Dubai.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2005_59-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2005-59">[59]</a></sup> Federer lost the year-end championships to <a href="/wiki/David_Nalbandian" title="David Nalbandian">David Nalbandian</a> in five sets while playing through a foot injury that sidelined him for almost the rest of the season after September.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> He maintained his position as No. 1 for the entire season.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2005_59-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2005-59">[59]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer won 11 singles titles, which ties his 2004 season. Federer's 81 match victories were the most since <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a> in 1993, and his record of 81â4 (95.2%) remains the third-best winning percentage in the Open Era behind <a href="/wiki/John_McEnroe" title="John McEnroe">John McEnroe</a>'s 1984 and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Connors" title="Jimmy Connors">Jimmy Connors</a>'s 1974.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2006:_Career-best_season">2006: Career-best season</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2006_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2006 Roger Federer tennis season">2006 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div>
      <p> The 2006 season was statistically the best season of Federer's career. In November 2011, Stephen Tignor, chief editorial writer for <a href="/wiki/Tennis.com" class="mw-redirect" title="Tennis.com">Tennis.com</a>, ranked Federer's 2006 season as statistically the second-best season of all time during the Open Era, behind <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a>'s Grand Slam year of 1969.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:277px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg/275px-Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg" decoding="async" width="275" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg/413px-Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg/550px-Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1017" data-file-height="678"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Amazing_Roger_Federer.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer hits a forehand at the 2006 US Open, where he became the first man in history to achieve the Wimbledon-US Open double for three consecutive seasons
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p> Federer won 12 singles titles (the most of any player since Thomas Muster in 1995 and John McEnroe in 1984) and had a match record of 92â5 (the most wins since Ivan Lendl in 1982). Federer reached the finals in an astounding 16 of the 17 tournaments he entered during the season.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In 2006, Federer won three Grand Slam singles titles and reached the final of the other, with the only loss coming against Nadal in the <a href="/wiki/2006_French_Open" title="2006 French Open">French Open</a>. This was Federer and Nadal's first meeting in a Grand Slam final.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2006_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2006-62">[62]</a></sup> He was the first man to reach all four finals in a calendar year since Rod Laver in 1969. Federer defeated Nadal in the <a href="/wiki/2006_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2006 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon Championships</a> final. In the <a href="/wiki/2006_Australian_Open" title="2006 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, Federer defeated <a href="/wiki/Marcos_Baghdatis" title="Marcos Baghdatis">Marcos Baghdatis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-RF2006_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2006-62">[62]</a></sup> and at the <a href="/wiki/2006_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2006 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, Federer defeated Roddick (2003 champion).<sup id="cite_ref-RF2006_62-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2006-62">[62]</a></sup> In addition, Federer made it to six ATP Masters Series 1000 finals, winning four on hard surfaces and losing two on clay to Nadal. Federer, however, consistently pushed Nadal to the limit on clay throughout the season taking him to fourth-set tiebreakers in Monte-Carlo and Paris, and a thrilling match in Rome that went to a deciding fifth-set tiebreaker.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer won one ATP 500 series event in Tokyo and captured the year-end championships for the third time in his career, again finishing the year as world No. 1.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2006_62-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2006-62">[62]</a></sup> Federer only lost to two players during 2006, to Nadal four times in finals, and to 19-year-old <a href="/wiki/Andy_Murray" title="Andy Murray">Andy Murray</a> in the second round of the <a href="/wiki/2006_Cincinnati_Masters" class="mw-redirect" title="2006 Cincinnati Masters">2006 Cincinnati Masters</a>, in what was Federer's only defeat before reaching the final of a tournament that year. Federer finished the season on a 29-match winning streak, as well as winning 48 of his last 49 matches after the French Open.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Near the end of the season he won his hometown tournament, the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a> in Basel, Switzerland for the first time, having finished runner up in 2000 and 2001, and missing the tournament in 2004 and 2005 due to injuries.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2007:_Holding_off_young_rivals">2007: Holding off young rivals</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2007_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2007 Roger Federer tennis season">2007 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div>
      <p> In 2007, Federer reached all four Grand Slam singles finals, winning three of them again. He won the <a href="/wiki/2007_Australian_Open" title="2007 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> without dropping a set, beating <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Gonz%C3%A1lez" title="Fernando GonzÃ¡lez">Fernando GonzÃ¡lez</a> in the final. This made him the first man in the 21st century to accomplish the feat, as <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Borg" title="BjÃ¶rn Borg">BjÃ¶rn Borg</a> at the 1980 French Open was the last to win a Grand Slam tournament without the loss of a set.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> Federer had entered the year on a huge winning streak and after capturing his fourth Dubai crown Federer's winning streak stood at 41 matches, the longest of his career and only five shy of the record. Federer entered Indian Wells as the three-time defending champion, but his streak ended in controversy. He was defeated by an Argentine, <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Ca%C3%B1as" title="Guillermo CaÃ±as">Guillermo CaÃ±as</a>, who had failed a drug test for illegal doping.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Mighty_Federer_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/The_Mighty_Federer_cropped.jpg/220px-The_Mighty_Federer_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="284" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5d/The_Mighty_Federer_cropped.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="237" data-file-height="306"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Mighty_Federer_cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer was coined "Darth Federer" by fans and commentators at the 2007 US Open
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p> This surprising first-round defeat marked the first time since August 2006 he suffered defeat, a period spanning over seven months.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>During the clay season, Federer's victory in the Hamburg Masters final was particularly impressive, as it snapped Nadal's 81-match winning streak on clay, an Open-era record. Federer turned the match around from a set down to sweep 12 of the final 14 games, including a final set <a href="/wiki/Bagel_(tennis)" title="Bagel (tennis)">bagel</a>. At the French Open, some anticipated that Federer could become the first man in almost 40 years to hold all four majors simultaneously, having just resoundingly defeated young rival Nadal on clay entering the tournament. However, in a repeat of the previous year Federer played a tough four-set final against Nadal, but was undone by going 1/17 on break-point chances.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At <a href="/wiki/2007_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2007 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, Federer entered the tournament not only as the four-time defending champion, but also riding a 48-match winning streak on grass. Once again, he defeated Rafael Nadal for a second consecutive year in the final, this time in a <a href="/wiki/2007_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles_final" class="mw-redirect" title="2007 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles final">thrilling five-set encounter</a> that many analysts hailed as the greatest Wimbledon final since <a href="/wiki/1980_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles_final" class="mw-redirect" title="1980 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles final">1980</a>. Victory at Wimbledon equaled him with <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Borg" title="BjÃ¶rn Borg">BjÃ¶rn Borg</a> for the record of five consecutive championships at the <a href="/wiki/All_England_Club" class="mw-redirect" title="All England Club">All England Club</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer reached the final in Montreal before playing a young and relatively unknown Serbian named <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>. Djokovic proved his potential by beating the world No. 1 in a final-set tiebreaker upset. Federer rebounded in Cincinnati to capture his fifth title of the year. Federer entered the <a href="/wiki/2007_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2007 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> as the three-time defending champion and faced Djokovic in the final. This time, Federer prevailed in a close straight-set match. Victory in New York moved him ahead of Laver and Borg for third on the all-time list of major championship victories. Throughout the tournament, the American press labelled him Darth Federer for his all-black attire (which included tuxedo-striped shorts) and the tournament played <a href="/wiki/The_Imperial_March" title="The Imperial March">The Imperial March</a> from <a href="/wiki/Star_Wars" title="Star Wars">Star Wars</a> when he was announced onto the court for each of his matches.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> He closed out the year with victories in <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Basel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Finals">Year End Championships</a> in Shanghai.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>He finished the season as the year-end No. 1 for the fourth year in a row, demonstrating his dominance, and during these four years he won 11 Grand Slam singles titles. After his phenomenal triple Grand Slam season yet again, Federer became the only player in history to win three Majors in a year for three years (2004, 2006, 2007).<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> It was the third consecutive season that Federer held the No. 1 ranking for all 52 weeks of the year.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2008:_Illness.2C_Olympic_Gold_and_fifth_US_Open"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2008:_Illness,_Olympic_Gold_and_fifth_US_Open">2008: Illness, Olympic Gold and fifth US Open</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2008_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2008 Roger Federer tennis season">2008 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer's success in 2008 was severely hampered by a lingering bout of <a href="/wiki/Mononucleosis" class="mw-redirect" title="Mononucleosis">mononucleosis</a>, which he suffered from during the first half of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> At the end of the year he suffered a back injury.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In 2008, Federer captured one Grand Slam, a singles title at the <a href="/wiki/2008_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2008 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> over Andy Murray.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2008_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2008-72">[72]</a></sup> Federer was defeated by Nadal in two Grand Slam finals, the <a href="/wiki/2008_French_Open" title="2008 French Open">French Open</a> and <a href="/wiki/2008_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2008 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, which was regarded as the best match of tennis history by many, when he was going for six straight wins to break <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Borg" title="BjÃ¶rn Borg">BjÃ¶rn Borg</a>'s record.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2008_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2008-72">[72]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2008_Australian_Open" title="2008 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, Federer lost in the semifinals to eventual winner Djokovic, which ended his record of 10 consecutive finals.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2008_72-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2008-72">[72]</a></sup> He lost twice in Masters Series 1000 finals on clay to Nadal, at Monte Carlo and Hamburg.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2008_72-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2008-72">[72]</a></sup> Federer captured three titles in 250-level events at Estoril, Halle, and Basel.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">Olympic Games</a>, Federer and <a href="/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka" title="Stan Wawrinka">Stan Wawrinka</a> won the gold medal in doubles, after beating the <a href="/wiki/Bryan_brothers" title="Bryan brothers">Bryan brothers</a> American team in the semifinals and the Swedish duo of <a href="/wiki/Simon_Aspelin" title="Simon Aspelin">Simon Aspelin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Johansson" title="Thomas Johansson">Thomas Johansson</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> However, Federer could only reach the quarterfinals in the singles draw, bowing out to then No. 8 <a href="/wiki/James_Blake_(tennis)" title="James Blake (tennis)">James Blake</a>, succumbing his No. 1 ranking to Nadal after being at the top for a record 237 consecutive weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> He ended the year ranked No. 2.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2009:_Career_Grand_Slam_and_Major_title_record">2009: Career Grand Slam and Major title record</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2009_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2009 Roger Federer tennis season">2009 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer entered the 2009 season with 13 Grand Slams, only one behind Pete Sampras' all-time record. The season began with a loss to Nadal in the final of the Australian Open in a hotly contested five-set match.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> Federer struggled following the defeat in Melbourne and entered the clay season without a title.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg/300px-Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg/450px-Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg/600px-Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2281" data-file-height="1286"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Roger_Federer_at_the_2009_French_Open_6.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer winning the French Open, and completing the career Grand Slam.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer's season turned around in the final masters event of the clay season when he defeated Nadal on clay for only the second time to capture the <a href="/wiki/Madrid_Open_(tennis)" title="Madrid Open (tennis)">Madrid Masters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2009_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2009-76">[76]</a></sup> Federer entered the French Open with few predicting him to win the elusive Parisian title having lost to Nadal in the final weekend for the past four seasons. After Nadal's unexpected defeat to <a href="/wiki/Robin_S%C3%B6derling" title="Robin SÃ¶derling">Robin SÃ¶derling</a>, Federer became the overwhelming favorite. In his next match, he came from two sets and break point down in the third set to defeat <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Haas" title="Tommy Haas">Tommy Haas</a> in five sets.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2009_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2009-76">[76]</a></sup> He also fought back from a two-sets-to-one deficit against a young <a href="/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro" title="Juan MartÃ­n del Potro">Juan MartÃ­n del Potro</a> to win a five setter in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2009_76-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2009-76">[76]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/2009_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final" title="2009 French Open â Men's singles final">the final</a>, he faced SÃ¶derling, and with straight sets victory, he finally captured the <a href="/wiki/Coupe_des_Mousquetaires" title="Coupe des Mousquetaires">Coupe des Mousquetaires</a> and career Grand Slam.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> This victory also tied him with Pete Sampras for the most Grand Slam singles titles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer turned his sights to the grass courts of Wimbledon, where he breezed his way up to the final.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In the championship match he faced long-time rival <a href="/wiki/Andy_Roddick" title="Andy Roddick">Andy Roddick</a> in what was their eighth and final meeting at a Grand Slam.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Roddick pushed Federer into a record-setting fifth set,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> which Federer claimed 16â14 to win his 15th Grand Slam singles title,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> breaking the all-time record of Pete Sampras.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer continued his summer run by winning his third title on the lightning-fast courts of the <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters" title="Cincinnati Masters">Cincinnati Masters</a>, defeating Novak Djokovic in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2009_76-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2009-76">[76]</a></sup> At the US Open he defeated SÃ¶derling in the quarters and Djokovic, for the third consecutive year, in the semifinals. On the penultimate point of the Djokovic match he hit what many consider to be the greatest shot of his career, a <a href="/wiki/Tweener_(tennis)" title="Tweener (tennis)">tweener</a> winner, to set up match points.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> Federer played del Potro in the final and led two sets to one before ultimately losing a fourth-set tiebreaker and subsequently the match.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2009_76-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2009-76">[76]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The 2009 season was perhaps the most historically relevant of Federer's career as he completed a career Grand Slam by winning his first French Open title and won a men's record fifteenth Grand Slam singles title at Wimbledon, surpassing Pete Sampras's mark of fourteen.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2009_76-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2009-76">[76]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2009_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2009 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">Wimbledon final</a> was also historic for being the longest Grand Slam final in terms of games played with Federer prevailing 16â14 in the fifth set.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer finished the season as the year-end No. 1 for the fifth time in his career.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2010:_Fourth_Australian_Open">2010: Fourth Australian Open</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2010_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2010 Roger Federer tennis season">2010 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:R_federer.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/R_federer.jpg/220px-R_federer.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="278" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/R_federer.jpg/330px-R_federer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/R_federer.jpg/440px-R_federer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1983" data-file-height="2507"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:R_federer.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer won a record 16th Major at the 2010 Australian Open
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer started the year with a win at the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_Open" title="2010 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-RF2010_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2010-79">[79]</a></sup> where he defeated Andy Murray in the final, extending the Grand Slam singles record to sixteen titles and matching <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a>'s record of four Australian Open titles.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2008_72-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2008-72">[72]</a></sup> Since Wimbledon 2005 Federer had made 18 out of 19 finals in Grand Slam tournaments, a period of sustained excellence unparalleled in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_tennis" title="History of tennis">Open Era</a>. This tournament, however, marked the end of his dominance at the majors.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2010_French_Open" title="2010 French Open">French Open</a>, Federer won his 700th tour match and 150th tour match on clay.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2010_79-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2010-79">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> However, he failed to reach a Grand Slam semifinal for the first time since the <a href="/wiki/2004_French_Open" title="2004 French Open">2004 French Open</a>, losing to SÃ¶derling in the last 8 and relinquishing his No. 1 ranking,<sup id="cite_ref-RF2010_79-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2010-79">[79]</a></sup> having been just one week away from equalling <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a>'s record of 286 weeks as world No. 1. In a huge upset at Wimbledon, Federer lost in the last 8 again to <a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych" title="TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych">TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych</a> and fell to No. 3 in the rankings for the first time in 6 years and 8 months.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2010_79-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2010-79">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Towards the middle of July, Federer hired Pete Sampras' old coach <a href="/wiki/Paul_Annacone" title="Paul Annacone">Paul Annacone</a> on a trial basis to put his tennis game and career back on track.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2010_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2010 US Open â Men's Singles">2010 US Open</a>, Federer reached the semifinals, where he lost a five-set match to Novak Djokovic after holding two match points.<sup id="cite_ref-RF2010_79-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RF2010-79">[79]</a></sup> Federer made it to four <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Masters 1000">Masters 1000</a> finals, prevailing at the <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters" title="Cincinnati Masters">Cincinnati Masters</a> against <a href="/wiki/Mardy_Fish" title="Mardy Fish">Mardy Fish</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer finished the year in strong form, winning indoor titles at the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_Open" title="Stockholm Open">Stockholm Open</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Finals">ATP World Tour Finals</a> in London, which brought his tally to 66 career titles. Federer won the year-end championships in London by beating rival Rafael Nadal for his fifth title at the event. He beat all contenders except Nadal in straight sets. It remains the only tournament in his career where Federer defeated all fellow members of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis)" title="Big Four (tennis)">Big Four</a>. Since Wimbledon 2010, Federer had a win-loss record of 34â4. Federer finished in the top two for the eighth consecutive season.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2011:_Tour_Finals_title_record">2011: Tour Finals title record</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2011_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2011 Roger Federer tennis season">2011 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The year 2011 was a lean year for Federer, although great by most player's standards. He was defeated in straight sets in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2011_Australian_Open" title="2011 Australian Open">2011 Australian Open</a> by eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> marking the first time since July 2003 that he did not hold any of the four major titles. In the <a href="/wiki/2011_French_Open" title="2011 French Open">French Open</a> semifinals, Federer ended Djokovic's undefeated streak of 43 consecutive wins with a four-set victory. Federer then lost in the final to Rafael Nadal. At Wimbledon, Federer advanced to his 29th consecutive Grand Slam quarterfinal, losing to <a href="/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga" title="Jo-Wilfried Tsonga">Jo-Wilfried Tsonga</a>. It marked the first time in his career that he had lost a Grand Slam tournament match after winning the first two sets.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2011_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2011 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, Federer lost in the semifinals to Novak Djokovic in five sets. In a repeat of previous year's semifinal event, Federer again squandered two match points on his own serve before losing after winning first two sets for second consecutive time in the year. Also, this loss meant that it was the first time since 2002 that Federer didn't win any of the four grand slam titles.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 2011, in a South African poll, Federer was voted the second most trusted and respected person in the world, next to <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer finished the season successfully in the indoor season, winning his last three tournaments of the year at the <a href="/wiki/2011_Swiss_Indoors_Basel" class="mw-redirect" title="2011 Swiss Indoors Basel">Swiss Indoors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_Masters" title="Paris Masters">Paris Masters</a>, and <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Finals">ATP World Tour Finals</a>, forming a 16 match winning streak. Federer finished the year ranked No. 3.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2012:_Wimbledon_title.2C_return_to_No._1_and_Olympic_Silver"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2012:_Wimbledon_title,_return_to_No._1_and_Olympic_Silver">2012: Wimbledon title, return to No. 1 and Olympic Silver</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2012_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2012 Roger Federer tennis season">2012 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The 2012 season for Federer had his most match wins since 2006 and his highest winning percentage and number of titles won since 2007.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer reached the semifinal of the <a href="/wiki/2012_Australian_Open" title="2012 Australian Open">2012 Australian Open</a>, setting up a 27th career meeting with Nadal, a match he lost in four sets.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> He then won the <a href="/wiki/2012_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament" title="2012 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament">Rotterdam Open</a> for the first time since 2005, defeating Juan MartÃ­n del Potro. Federer played in the <a href="/wiki/2012_Dubai_Tennis_Championships" title="2012 Dubai Tennis Championships">2012 Dubai Tennis Championships</a>, where he defeated Andy Murray in the final and won the championship title for the fifth time in his career. Federer then moved on to the <a href="/wiki/2012_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2012 BNP Paribas Open">Indian Wells Masters</a>, where he defeated Rafael Nadal in the semifinals, and <a href="/wiki/John_Isner" title="John Isner">John Isner</a> in the final. Federer won the title for a record fourth time, and, in doing so, equalled Nadal's record of 19 ATP Masters 1000 titles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg/300px-Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg/450px-Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg/600px-Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="576"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Federer_Wimbledon_2012_Champion.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer won a record 17th Major, a record-equaling 7th Wimbledon, and returned to No. 1.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer went on to compete at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Mutua_Madrid_Open" title="2012 Mutua Madrid Open">Madrid Masters</a> on the new blue clay surface, where he beat TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych in the final, thus regaining the No. 2 ranking from Rafael Nadal. In the <a href="/wiki/2012_French_Open" title="2012 French Open">French Open</a>, Federer made the semifinals before losing to Djokovic in straight sets, in a rematch of previous year's semifinal.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At <a href="/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2012 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, Federer had a five-set match in the third round against <a href="/wiki/Julien_Benneteau" title="Julien Benneteau">Julien Benneteau</a> on his way to the winning the tournament. Federer defeated Andy Murray in four sets in the 2012 Wimbledon final,<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> regaining the No. 1 ranking in the process.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> "It's amazing. It equals me with Pete Sampras, who's my hero. It just feels amazing", Federer said of winning his seventh Wimbledon championship, tying Sampras' Open Era record.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> By defeating top-ranked Djokovic in the semifinals and winning in the finals, Federer returned to the top spot in the world rankings and, in doing so, broke Sampras' record of 286 weeks atop the list.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, Federer played a 4-hour 26-minute semifinal against del Potro where Federer won 19â17 in the third and final set.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> In a lopsided match, he lost to Murray in straight sets in the final, winning a silver medal for his country.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer won the Cincinnati open in August, beating <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2012 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, five-time champ Federer was defeated by TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych in the quarterfinals.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the Shanghai Masters, after defeating Wawrinka in the third round, Federer confirmed his 300th week at No. 1. Federer made it to the finals of the ATP Finals, where he lost to Djokovic in two sets.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2013:_Injury_struggles.2C_fall_in_rankings"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2013:_Injury_struggles,_fall_in_rankings">2013: Injury struggles, fall in rankings</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2013_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2013 Roger Federer tennis season">2013 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer developed back injuries in March and July and his ranking dropped from No. 2 to No. 6. The 2013 season was the first since 1999 in which Federer failed to reach a final in the first four months of the year.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer's first and only title of 2013 came at the <a href="/wiki/Gerry_Weber_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Gerry Weber Open">Gerry Weber Open</a> (defeating <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Youzhny" title="Mikhail Youzhny">Mikhail Youzhny</a>), where he also played doubles with good friend <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Haas" title="Tommy Haas">Tommy Haas</a>. With the victory in <a href="/wiki/Halle,_North_Rhine-Westphalia" class="mw-redirect" title="Halle, North Rhine-Westphalia">Halle</a>, he tied John McEnroe for the third-most number of ATP titles won by a male player in the Open Era.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> Federer, however, was unable to maintain his form into Wimbledon, suffering his worst Grand Slam tournament defeat since 2003 in the second round against <a href="/wiki/Sergiy_Stakhovsky" title="Sergiy Stakhovsky">Sergiy Stakhovsky</a>. Not only did the loss end Federer's record streak of 36 consecutive quarterfinals at Grand Slam tournaments,<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> it meant he would drop out of the top 4 for the first time since July 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> </p>
