      <p>During the summer, he experimented with various different racquets and played the <a href="/wiki/2013_International_German_Open" title="2013 International German Open">German Open</a> with a blacked-out 98-inch Wilson racquet, instead of his regular Pro Staff 6.1 90 BLX racquet with the smaller 90-inch hitting area. He returned to his regular racquet for the second half of the season.<sup id="cite_ref-2013racquet_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013racquet-105">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> After Wimbledon, Federer continued to be upset early in tournaments in <a href="/wiki/2013_International_German_Open" title="2013 International German Open">Hamburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/2013_Cr%C3%A9dit_Agricole_Suisse_Open_Gstaad" title="2013 CrÃ©dit Agricole Suisse Open Gstaad">Gstaad</a> because of a serious back injury through October, when he announced that he was parting ways with Paul Annacone, his coach for the last three years.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> Federer made the final in Basel, succumbing to <a href="/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro" title="Juan MartÃ­n del Potro">Juan MartÃ­n del Potro</a> in three sets, and indicated it was a mistake to have played certain tournaments while suffering from a back injury.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 27 December 2013, Federer announced that <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Edberg" title="Stefan Edberg">Stefan Edberg</a> was joining his team as co-coach with <a href="/wiki/Severin_L%C3%BCthi" title="Severin LÃ¼thi">Severin LÃ¼thi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2014:_Davis_Cup_glory">2014: Davis Cup glory</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2014_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2014 Roger Federer tennis season">2014 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer began the season by changing rackets for the first time in his career, from his longtime frame of 90 square inches to one measured at 97 square inches. He had long been at a comparative disadvantage in equipment as almost the entire tour, including his top rivals Nadal and Djokovic, used more powerful frames of between 95 and 100 square inches.<sup id="cite_ref-2013racquet_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013racquet-105">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> At the Australian Open, Federer defeated Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and Andy Murray to reach his 11th consecutive semifinal in Melbourne, before losing to Rafael Nadal in straight sets.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/Dubai_Tennis_Championships" title="Dubai Tennis Championships">Dubai Tennis Championships</a>, he defeated Novak Djokovic in the semifinals, and then defeated TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych in the final to win his sixth Dubai crown and his first title since Halle in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Federer made the final at the <a href="/wiki/2014_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2014 BNP Paribas Open">Indian Wells Masters</a>, but lost to Novak Djokovic in a final-set tiebreaker. At the Davis Cup quarterfinals, Federer won both of his singles rubbers against Kazakhstan, the second of which was the first live deciding rubber of his Davis Cup career. Federer then took a wild card into the <a href="/wiki/2014_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters" title="2014 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters">Monte-Carlo Masters</a> defeating Novak Djokovic on his way to the finals, but lost to compatriot Stan Wawrinka in a tight final.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In June, Federer announced that after the end of his third term, he would resign as President of the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals#Organizational_structure" title="Association of Tennis Professionals">ATP Players Council</a>, a position he had held since 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2014_Gerry_Weber_Open" title="2014 Gerry Weber Open">Halle Open</a>, Federer reached both the singles and the doubles finals and won his seventh Halle singles title, beating <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Falla" title="Alejandro Falla">Alejandro Falla</a> in the final. At Wimbledon, Federer reached a record ninth final, but he was defeated by Djokovic in an <a href="/wiki/2014_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final" title="2014 Wimbledon Championships â Men's singles final">epic five-set match</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Match_Federer-Gasquet_(Coupe_Davis_2014).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Match_Federer-Gasquet_%28Coupe_Davis_2014%29.JPG/260px-Match_Federer-Gasquet_%28Coupe_Davis_2014%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="260" height="199" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Match_Federer-Gasquet_%28Coupe_Davis_2014%29.JPG/390px-Match_Federer-Gasquet_%28Coupe_Davis_2014%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Match_Federer-Gasquet_%28Coupe_Davis_2014%29.JPG/520px-Match_Federer-Gasquet_%28Coupe_Davis_2014%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4399" data-file-height="3362"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Match_Federer-Gasquet_(Coupe_Davis_2014).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer receiving serve against Richard Gasquet in the title clinching match for Switzerland at the 2014 Davis Cup
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer made the final of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Rogers_Cup" title="2014 Rogers Cup">Canadian Open</a> but was defeated by Jo-Wilfried Tsonga. Federer defeated Spain's <a href="/wiki/David_Ferrer" title="David Ferrer">David Ferrer</a> in three sets to capture his sixth <a href="/wiki/2014_Western_%26_Southern_Open" title="2014 Western &amp; Southern Open">Cincinnati</a> crown and 22nd <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Masters 1000">ATP World Tour Masters 1000</a> title, his first in Cincinnati since 2012. He then reached the semifinals at the <a href="/wiki/2014_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2014 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> but lost in straight sets to eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87" title="Marin ÄiliÄ">Marin ÄiliÄ</a>. At the Davis Cup semifinals, Federer won both his singles matches against Italy in straight sets and led Switzerland to the final for the first time since 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer then played in the <a href="/wiki/2014_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters" title="2014 Shanghai Rolex Masters">Shanghai Masters</a>. He beat Novak Djokovic in the semifinals, ending the Serb's 28-match unbeaten run on Chinese soil. He battled Frenchman <a href="/wiki/Gilles_Simon" title="Gilles Simon">Gilles Simon</a> in his second Shanghai final, defeating him in two tiebreak sets and collected the 23rd Masters 1000 title of his career. The victory saw Federer return to the No. 2 ranking for the first time since May 2013. Federer then played the <a href="/wiki/2014_Swiss_Indoors" title="2014 Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a> in October, where he won a record sixth title and his 82nd ATP men's singles title overall. Federer also reached the finals of the <a href="/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2014 ATP World Tour Finals â Singles">2014 ATP World Tour Finals</a> to face Djokovic again, but withdrew from the final because of another back injury from his semifinal match against Stan Wawrinka.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Despite his injury, Federer finished the season on a high by defeating <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gasquet" title="Richard Gasquet">Richard Gasquet</a> to clinch the <a href="/wiki/2014_Davis_Cup" title="2014 Davis Cup">Davis Cup</a> for Switzerland for the first time in its history.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> The final was held at the <a href="/wiki/Stade_Pierre-Mauroy" title="Stade Pierre-Mauroy">Stade Pierre-Mauroy</a> in Lille, France attracting over 27,000 spectators per match; this broke attendance record for the highest ever officially sanctioned competition tennis match.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2015:_1.2C000th_victory.2C_Wimbledon_.26_US_Open_finals"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2015:_1,000th_victory,_Wimbledon_&amp;_US_Open_finals">2015: 1,000th victory, Wimbledon &amp; US Open finals</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2015_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2015 Roger Federer tennis season">2015 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer started his season at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Brisbane_International" title="2015 Brisbane International">Brisbane International</a>. He defeated <a href="/wiki/Milos_Raonic" title="Milos Raonic">Milos Raonic</a> in the final, thereby becoming only the third man in the Open Era to have 1,000 or more wins, joining <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Connors" title="Jimmy Connors">Jimmy Connors</a> and Ivan Lendl, as well as the first man in the Open Era to win at least one title in each of 15 consecutive years.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In Dubai, Federer successfully defended his title with a straight-set victory over Novak Djokovic in the final, marking his seventh title at the tournament and, after <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon_championships" class="mw-redirect" title="Wimbledon championships">Wimbledon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Halle_Open" title="Halle Open">Halle</a>, was the third time he had won seven or more titles in a tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Additionally, Federer became the fourth person since 1991 to surpass 9,000 career aces.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> In March, he reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/2015_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2015 BNP Paribas Open â Men's Singles">Indian Wells</a>, but lost in three sets to defending champion Djokovic.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer won his third title of the season at the inaugural <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Open" title="Istanbul Open">Istanbul Open</a> clay-court tournament, ending a title drought on red clay since the <a href="/wiki/2009_French_Open" title="2009 French Open">2009 French Open</a>. Federer made it to the final of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" class="mw-redirect" title="2015 Internazionali BNL d'Italia â Men's Singles">Italian Open</a> in May, but was unable to win his first title there, losing to Djokovic in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2015_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2015 French Open â Men's Singles">French Open</a> he made it through the first rounds losing just one set, to <a href="/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils" title="GaÃ«l Monfils">GaÃ«l Monfils</a> in the 4th. In the quarterfinals, he was eventually beaten in straight sets by the later champion <a href="/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka" title="Stan Wawrinka">Stan Wawrinka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As the new expanded grass season began, Federer won his record eighth <a href="/wiki/2015_Gerry_Weber_Open" title="2015 Gerry Weber Open">Gerry Weber Open</a> and become only the third man in the Open Era to win a title eight times.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> Federer entered <a href="/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2015 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a> as the second seed. He played a flawless match to defeat Andy Murray in straight sets in the semifinals and advance to his 10th Wimbledon final in a repeat against Novak Djokovic. Federer lost the match in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>He defeated Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic in straight sets to win the Cincinnati Masters for the seventh time. This marked the first time that Federer had beaten the top two players in the world at the same tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2015_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2015 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, he advanced to his first final there since 2009 without dropping a set, including a win over Stan Wawrinka in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> In the final, he was once again defeated by top seed Djokovic in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a> tournament in Basel, Federer won his sixth singles title of the year, and his 88th ATP title, defeating his old rival Rafael Nadal in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> It was the seventh time he had captured his hometown tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In December, Federer announced that he would enter the 2016 ATP World Tour season with a new-look coaching team, having additionally announced that Stefan Edberg would not be travelling with him next year. While countryman Severin LÃ¼thi remained Federer's head coach, joining the team in 2016 was Croatian former world No. 3 player <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Ljubicic" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan Ljubicic">Ivan Ljubicic</a>. Federer revealed that Edberg originally signed on to the coaching team for one season only in 2014, but agreed to stay on in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2016:_Knee_surgery.2C_back_injury_.26_long_recovery_hiatus"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2016:_Knee_surgery,_back_injury_&amp;_long_recovery_hiatus">2016: Knee surgery, back injury &amp; long recovery hiatus</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2016_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2016 Roger Federer tennis season">2016 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer started his season in the <a href="/wiki/2016_Brisbane_International_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2016 Brisbane International â Men's Singles">Brisbane International</a> as the defending champion, despite having a virus when the tournament started. However, in a rematch of the previous year's final, he lost in the final to Milos Raonic in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Federer then participated at the <a href="/wiki/2016_Australian_Open_-_Men%27s_Singles" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Australian Open - Men's Singles">2016 Australian Open</a> and rebounded from his third round defeat by <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Seppi" title="Andreas Seppi">Andreas Seppi</a> in <a href="/wiki/2015_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2015 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2015</a> by reaching the semifinals but lost to eventual champion Novak Djokovic in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> The day after his loss to Djokovic, Federer sustained a knee injury and in early February, he underwent <a href="/wiki/Arthroscopic_surgery" class="mw-redirect" title="Arthroscopic surgery">arthroscopic surgery</a> to repair a <a href="/wiki/Torn_meniscus" class="mw-redirect" title="Torn meniscus">torn meniscus</a> in his knee and missed the tournaments in <a href="/wiki/2016_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament" title="2016 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament">Rotterdam</a>, <a href="/wiki/2016_Dubai_Tennis_Championships" title="2016 Dubai Tennis Championships">Dubai</a> and <a href="/wiki/2016_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2016 BNP Paribas Open">Indian Wells</a> in February and March. He was scheduled to return to action in <a href="/wiki/2016_Miami_Open_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Miami Open (tennis)">Miami</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> Due to a stomach virus he had to withdraw from <a href="/wiki/2016_Miami_Open_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Miami Open (tennis)">Miami</a> thus prolonging his time on the sidelines.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer made his comeback at the <a href="/wiki/Monte-Carlo_Masters" title="Monte-Carlo Masters">Monte-Carlo Masters</a>, losing in the quarterfinals to Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in three sets. In Madrid, he suffered a back injury during practice and withdrew shortly after arriving. He then participated in the <a href="/wiki/2016_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Internazionali BNL d'Italia</a> where he lost in the third round to <a href="/wiki/Dominic_Thiem" title="Dominic Thiem">Dominic Thiem</a>. His withdrawal from the <a href="/wiki/2016_French_Open" title="2016 French Open">French Open</a> broke a record run of 65 consecutive participations in the main draw of Grand Slam tournaments, stretching back to the <a href="/wiki/2000_Australian_Open" title="2000 Australian Open">2000 Australian Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Still suffering from recurring knee pain during the grass season he lost in the semifinals of Stuttgart and Halle. On 6 July, he came back from two sets down to defeat Marin ÄiliÄ in five sets in the 2016 Wimbledon quarterfinals, equalling Jimmy Connors' all-time records of eleven Wimbledon semifinals and 84 match wins.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> He suffered his first defeat in a Wimbledon semifinal two days later in a five-set loss to Raonic, re-injuring his knee in the fifth set.<sup id="cite_ref-:63_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:63-138">[138]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 26 July, Federer announced that he would miss the <a href="/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics" title="2016 Summer Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a> and the remainder of the 2016 season to fully recover from his knee injury.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> The sudden withdrawal not only implied that 2016 was his first season since 2000 that Federer failed to win a title, but it also meant that he would have to drop out of top ten for the first time in fourteen years. This, combined with a grand slam drought spanning over four years, led to many analysts believing that his outstanding career was finally coming to an end and he would never win any major titles again.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2017:_Renaissance.2C_Australian_Open_.26_Wimbledon_titles"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2017:_Renaissance,_Australian_Open_&amp;_Wimbledon_titles">2017: Renaissance, Australian Open &amp; Wimbledon titles</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2017_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2017 Roger Federer tennis season">2017 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer's 2017 season marked a return to Grand Slam wins since 2012, the most titles since 2007, and the highest win percentage since 2006. Statistically, this season was his best since 2007.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Federer played in the <a href="/wiki/2017_Hopman_Cup" title="2017 Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> and <a href="/wiki/2017_Australian_Open" title="2017 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> in January 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> His withdrawal from most of the injury affected 2016 season lead his ranking slip to No. 17 at the start of Australian Open, his lowest in over fifteen years. At the Australian Open, he beat top-10 players TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych and <a href="/wiki/Kei_Nishikori" title="Kei Nishikori">Kei Nishikori</a> on his way to semifinals, making Federer the oldest man to compete in a grand slam semi-final since Jimmy Connors in 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> In the semi-finals, he defeated Stanislas Wawrinka in five sets, making him the oldest player to compete in a Grand Slam final since <a href="/wiki/Ken_Rosewall" title="Ken Rosewall">Ken Rosewall</a> in 1974.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Coming back from a break down in the fifth set, Federer defeated Rafael Nadal to win the Australian Open, which also marked Federer's 100th match at the Australian Open; it was the first time Federer had won a match against Nadal in a Grand Slam event since the <a href="/wiki/2007_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final" title="2007 Wimbledon Championships â Men's singles final">2007 Wimbledon final</a>, and also marked Federer's first ever Grand Slam victory over Nadal outside the grass courts of Wimbledon. With this victory, he re-entered the top ten.<sup id="cite_ref-ATP10th-on30Jan2017_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ATP10th-on30Jan2017-146">[146]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In March, Federer won his 25th Masters title at <a href="/wiki/2017_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 BNP Paribas Open â Men's Singles">Indian Wells</a>, defeating Wawrinka in the final and gaining another victory over Nadal in the 4th round. This was also Federer's 90th career title and he climbed to No. 6 in the ATP rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Federer collected his 26th Masters title by defeating Nadal in the final of the <a href="/wiki/2017_Miami_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 Miami Open â Men's Singles">Miami Masters</a> in straight sets and climbed to No. 4 in the ATP rankings. This marked the third time Federer had won in Indian Wells and Miami back-to-back, colloquially referred to as the Sunshine Double (2005, 2006 and 2017).<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Due to concerns about his longevity, Federer decided that he would skip the entire clay-court season.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> He returned to the tour at the beginning of the grass-court season in Stuttgart, where he suffered a shock defeat to Tommy Haas in the second round despite holding match points, the lowest-ranked player (No. 302) to beat him since No. 407 Bjoern Phau in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> He rebounded the following week by winning a record-extending ninth title at the <a href="/wiki/Halle_Open" title="Halle Open">Gerry Weber Open</a> in Halle, doing so without the loss of a set.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2017 Wimbledon Championships</a>, Federer made it to the final without dropping a set, defeating Milos Raonic in the quarterfinals and TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych in the semifinals. In the final, Federer defeated a physically and mentally out of sorts Marin ÄiliÄ in straight sets to win a record-breaking eighth Wimbledon gentlemen's singles title and his record-extending 19th major title overall, becoming the oldest male player to win Wimbledon in the Open era.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> Federer became the second man in the Open era to win Wimbledon without dropping a set after <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Borg" title="BjÃ¶rn Borg">BjÃ¶rn Borg</a> in <a href="/wiki/1976_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1976 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">1976</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> It marked the second time in his career that he had won a grand slam tournament without losing a set, matching his performance at the <a href="/wiki/2007_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2007 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2007 Australian Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> Federer moved up to become No. 3 in the ATP Rankings after the event and qualified for the ATP Finals for a record 15th time.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the opening of the summer hard court swing Federer was defeated in the final of the <a href="/wiki/2017_Rogers_Cup" title="2017 Rogers Cup">Montreal Masters</a> by Alexander Zverev after injuring his back during the match. Due to the injury, he opted to withdraw from the <a href="/wiki/2017_Western_%26_Southern_Open" title="2017 Western &amp; Southern Open">Cincinnati Masters</a> to be fit for the <a href="/wiki/2017_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2017 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>. However, Federer lost to del Potro in the quarterfinals at the US Open, in a tournament characterized by inconsistent play from Federer, unlike the major portion of the season.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer's next participation was in September in the inaugural <a href="/wiki/Laver_Cup" title="Laver Cup">Laver Cup</a>, representing team Europe. Federer won both his singles matches against <a href="/wiki/Sam_Querrey" title="Sam Querrey">Sam Querrey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nick_Kyrgios" title="Nick Kyrgios">Nick Kyrgios</a>, with the latter win sealing the cup for Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> The tournament was also notable for Federer playing doubles teaming with longtime rival Nadal for the first time. The two legends emerged victorious against world duo of Sam Querrey and <a href="/wiki/Jack_Sock" title="Jack Sock">Jack Sock</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2017_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2017 Shanghai Rolex Masters â Singles">Shanghai Masters</a>, Federer captured his third Masters title of the season, defeating No. 1 Rafael Nadal in the final. This was Federer's fifth straight victory over Nadal in their rivalry and his 94th career title, drawing him level with 2nd-placed Ivan Lendl.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> During the indoor season, Federer defeated Juan Martin Del Potro in the final of his hometown tournament, the <a href="/wiki/2017_Swiss_Indoors_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2017 Swiss Indoors â Singles">Swiss Indoors</a> in Basel, earning a record eighth championship there and winning his 95th career title, surpassing Ivan Lendl in number of career titles. Federer qualified for the <a href="/wiki/2017_ATP_Finals" title="2017 ATP Finals">2017 ATP Finals</a>, but was beaten by <a href="/wiki/David_Goffin" title="David Goffin">David Goffin</a> in the semifinals in three sets.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2018:_20th_Major_title_and_310_weeks_at_No._1">2018: 20th Major title and 310 weeks at No. 1</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2018_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2018 Roger Federer tennis season">2018 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer started his season winning the <a href="/wiki/2018_Hopman_Cup" title="2018 Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> partnering with <a href="/wiki/Belinda_Bencic" title="Belinda Bencic">Belinda Bencic</a>. This was his second Hopman Cup title, having won previously in 2001 with <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2018_Australian_Open_-_Men%27s_Singles" class="mw-redirect" title="2018 Australian Open - Men's Singles">2018 Australian Open</a>, Federer reached the final without dropping a set, and successfully defended his title beating Marin ÄiliÄ in a five-set final. This was Federer's sixth title at the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, equaling the then record held by <a href="/wiki/Roy_Emerson" title="Roy Emerson">Roy Emerson</a> and Novak Djokovic, which was surpassed by Djokovic in 2019. He also became the first man to win twenty <a href="/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_men%27s_singles_champions" title="List of Grand Slam men's singles champions">Grand Slam</a> titles. It was also the first time since the 2008 US Open that Federer successfully defended a major title.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In mid-February, Federer won his third <a href="/wiki/Rotterdam_Open" title="Rotterdam Open">Rotterdam Open</a> title to return to No. 1 in the ATP rankings, clinching the spot with a quarterfinal victory over <a href="/wiki/Robin_Haase" title="Robin Haase">Robin Haase</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> He beat <a href="/wiki/Grigor_Dimitrov" title="Grigor Dimitrov">Grigor Dimitrov</a> in straight sets in the final. At 36 years and 195 days of age, he became the oldest ATP world No. 1 by more than three years. He also broke the ATP record for the longest span between a player's first and last weeks to attain the No. 1 ranking at 14 years and 17 days apart, as well as the most time between two successive reigns at No. 1 at 5 years and 106 days.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In March, Federer entered the <a href="/wiki/2018_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2018 BNP Paribas Open">Indian Wells Masters</a> as <a href="/wiki/2017_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 BNP Paribas Open â Men's Singles">the defending champion</a>. He defeated <a href="/wiki/Chung_Hyeon" title="Chung Hyeon">Chung Hyeon</a> in the quarterfinals, ensuring that he retained the <a href="/wiki/ATP_ranking" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP ranking">world No. 1 ranking</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Borna_%C4%86ori%C4%87" title="Borna ÄoriÄ">Borna ÄoriÄ</a> in the semifinals, solidifying a career-best start to a season at 17â0. His previous best season start had been 16â0 during the 2006 season.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> Despite holding three championship points, Federer was defeated by Juan Martin Del Potro in a close three-set final. At the <a href="/wiki/2018_Miami_Open" title="2018 Miami Open">Miami Open</a>, Federer received a first-round bye, but lost in the second round to <a href="/wiki/Thanasi_Kokkinakis" title="Thanasi Kokkinakis">Thanasi Kokkinakis</a>. With this early exit from the tournament, Federer lost his No. 1 ranking to Nadal on 2 April. He announced that he would miss the clay court season, including the French Open, for the second consecutive season.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> Nevertheless, he regained the No. 1 ranking in May after Nadal failed to defend one of his Masters titles at the <a href="/wiki/2018_Mutua_Madrid_Open" title="2018 Mutua Madrid Open">Madrid Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> He then lost the top spot the following week after Nadal won the title at the <a href="/wiki/2018_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2018 Italian Open â Men's Singles">Italian Open</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In June, Federer regained the No. 1 ranking after defeating Nick Kyrgios in the semifinals at the <a href="/wiki/Stuttgart_Open" title="Stuttgart Open">Stuttgart Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> He then won the tournament, defeating Milos Raonic in the final in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> However, he lost his No.1 ranking the following week when he failed to defend his <a href="/wiki/Halle_Open" title="Halle Open">Halle Open</a> title, losing in the final to Borna ÄoriÄ in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2018 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">Wimbledon</a>, Federer was looking to defend his 2017 title and was seeded first at a Grand Slam for the first time since the <a href="/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2012 US Open (tennis)">2012 US Open</a> but lost in the quarter finals against South African <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Anderson_(tennis)" title="Kevin Anderson (tennis)">Kevin Anderson</a> in five sets, despite winning the first two sets and having a match point in the third set.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> This was only his second Wimbledon defeat after winning the first two sets since his defeat to Jo-Wilfried Tsonga at the <a href="/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2011 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2011 Wimbledon Championships</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer next played in <a href="/wiki/2018_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2018 Western &amp; Southern Open â Men's Singles">Cincinnati</a> where he lost in the final to Novak Djokovic, who won a record Career Golden Masters, in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> The loss ended Federer's run of 100 consecutive service holds and 14 match winning streak in Cincinnati. Federer entered the <a href="/wiki/2018_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2018 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> as the second seed but was upset by <a href="/wiki/John_Millman" title="John Millman">John Millman</a> in the 4th round, citing extreme conditions of heat and humidity that took a toll on his body.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> Federer then played at the <a href="/wiki/2018_Laver_Cup" title="2018 Laver Cup">Laver Cup</a> where he successfully helped Team Europe defend their title, winning both his singles matches against Nick Kyrgios and John Isner.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> He also paired up with Djokovic for the first time in doubles, losing their match against Jack Sock and Kevin Anderson in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> Federer then played at the <a href="/wiki/2018_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2018 Shanghai Rolex Masters â Singles">2018 Shanghai Masters</a> as the defending champion but lost in the semifinals to Borna ÄoriÄ in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2018_Swiss_Indoors_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2018 Swiss Indoors â Singles">Swiss Indoors</a> in October, Federer shared that he had sustained a hand injury in training prior to the grass season that had caused severe pain up his forearm. He stated that this injury significantly hindered his play, particularly his forehand, since the Stuttgart Open.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> Federer went on to defend his title with a straight-sets win over <a href="/wiki/Marius_Copil" title="Marius Copil">Marius Copil</a> in the final, winning his ninth title at the event and his 99th career singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Federer entered the <a href="/wiki/2018_Rolex_Paris_Masters" title="2018 Rolex Paris Masters">Paris Masters</a>, continuing his good run of form defeating Fabio Fognini and Kei Nishikori in straight sets. In the semi-finals, he played a very close match with Novak Djokovic, but ultimately lost to him in three sets. At the <a href="/wiki/2018_ATP_Finals" title="2018 ATP Finals">Nitto ATP Finals</a>, Federer lost in straight sets to Alexander Zverev in the semifinal.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2019:_Hopman_Cup_record.2C_100_titles.2C_1200_match_wins.2C_12th_Wimbledon_final"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2019:_Hopman_Cup_record,_100_titles,_1200_match_wins,_12th_Wimbledon_final">2019: Hopman Cup record, 100 titles, 1200 match wins, 12th Wimbledon final</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2019_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2019 Roger Federer tennis season">2019 Roger Federer tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer opened his campaign by retaining the <a href="/wiki/2019_Hopman_Cup" title="2019 Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> alongside Belinda Bencic, becoming the first player to win the mixed-gender event three times.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer was seeded third at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Australian_Open" title="2019 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, entering as the two-time defending champion. He defeated <a href="/wiki/Denis_Istomin" title="Denis Istomin">Denis Istomin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dan_Evans_(tennis)" title="Dan Evans (tennis)">Dan Evans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taylor_Fritz" title="Taylor Fritz">Taylor Fritz</a> to reach the fourth round, where he faced 14th seed <a href="/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas" title="Stefanos Tsitsipas">Stefanos Tsitsipas</a>. In a stunning upset, Tsitsipas defeated Federer in four close sets. Critically, Federer was unable to convert any of the twelve break points he held throughout the match, including four set points in the second set. After the match Federer announced he will play the clay court season for the first time since 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/Dubai_Tennis_Championships" title="Dubai Tennis Championships">Dubai Tennis Championships</a>, Federer won his 100th Career Singles Title, beating Tsitsipas in straight sets in the final. It was his eighth title in Dubai and he became only the second man after Jimmy Connors to reach the three figure mark in the Open Era.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> Federer then reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/2019_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 BNP Paribas Open â Men's Singles">2019 Indian Wells Masters</a> where he lost to <a href="/wiki/Dominic_Thiem" title="Dominic Thiem">Dominic Thiem</a> in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> On 31 March, Federer defeated John Isner at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Miami_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 Miami Open â Men's Singles">2019 Miami Open</a> in straights sets to win his 4th Miami Open title and 28th Masters 1000 title.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> Federer then played his first clay court tournament in three years at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 Mutua Madrid Open â Men's Singles">2019 Madrid Open</a> and secured his 1200th career win, beating Gael Monfils in the third round. In the quarterfinals he lost to Dominic Thiem again in three sets, despite having two match points in the second set.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> Federer then played at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 Italian Open â Men's Singles">Italian Open</a> and reached the quarterfinals but was forced to withdraw from his quarterfinal match against Stefanos Tsitsipas due to a right leg injury.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer next played at the <a href="/wiki/2019_French_Open" title="2019 French Open">French Open</a> for the first time in 4 years and seeded 3rd in the draw. Federer achieved comfortable straight-set victories against <a href="/wiki/Lorenzo_Sonego" title="Lorenzo Sonego">Lorenzo Sonego</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Otte" title="Oscar Otte">Oscar Otte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Casper_Ruud" title="Casper Ruud">Casper Ruud</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_Mayer" title="Leonardo Mayer">Leonardo Mayer</a> to reach the quarterfinals, where he faced good friend and compatriot Stan Wawrinka. Federer managed to avenge his loss to Wawrinka at the same stage of the tournament 4 years ago, winning in 4 sets after 3 hours and 35 minutes. With the victory Federer returned to the semifinals of the French Open for the first time since 2012, where he lost to 11-time champion Rafael Nadal in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer then began his grass court season at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Halle_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2019 Halle Open â Singles">2019 Halle Open</a> where he won his tenth title at the event, defeating David Goffin in the final in straight sets. This marked the first time Federer had won a singles tournament for ten times or more.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">Wimbledon championships</a>, Roger Federer reached his record 12th final at the tournament after ousting his nemesis Rafael Nadal in four sets in the semifinal, thus exacting revenge for his earlier defeat to him at the French Open. This was also the first time Federer played Nadal at Wimbledon since the <a href="/wiki/2008_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final" title="2008 Wimbledon Championships â Men's singles final">2008 Wimbledon final</a>, a match regarded by some as the greatest match in the history of tennis.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> Federer then faced Novak Djokovic in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final" title="2019 Wimbledon Championships â Men's singles final">final</a>, against whom he lost in a five set thriller lasting four hours and fifty seven minutes, despite having two championship points on serve in the fifth set. The match also marked the first time a fifth set tiebreaker was played at 12 games all in the men's singles and was the longest men's final in Wimbledon history.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer next played at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 Western &amp; Southern Open â Men's Singles">2019 Cincinnati Masters</a> and reached the third round where he lost in straight sets to <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Rublev_(tennis)" title="Andrey Rublev (tennis)">Andrey Rublev</a>. This was his quickest defeat in 16 years, taking just 62 minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2019_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2019 US Open (tennis)">2019 US Open</a>, he was seeded third. He dropped the first set against both <a href="/wiki/Sumit_Nagal" title="Sumit Nagal">Sumit Nagal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Damir_D%C5%BEumhur" title="Damir DÅ¾umhur">Damir DÅ¾umhur</a> in the first two rounds, but pulled out convincing straight sets wins over <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Evans_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="Daniel Evans (tennis)">Dan Evans</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Goffin" title="David Goffin">David Goffin</a> in the third and fourth. In the quarterfinals, he faced Grigor Dimitrov, who was ranked #78 going into the tournament. Despite taking a two sets to one lead, Federer ultimately lost the match in five sets.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2019_Rolex_Shanghai_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2019 Rolex Shanghai Masters â Singles">2019 Shanghai Masters</a>, Federer defeated <a href="/wiki/David_Goffin" title="David Goffin">David Goffin</a> in straight sets to reach the quarterfinal.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> However, he lost the quarterfinal to <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Zverev" title="Alexander Zverev">Alexander Zverev</a> in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer advanced to the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a> as the two-time defending champion. His first round match, against Peter Gojowczyk, is remarkable for being the 1500th match of his career. In the final, he defeated Alex de Minaur in straight sets for a record-extending tenth Swiss Indoors title.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="National_representation">National representation</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Davis_Cup">Davis Cup</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer made his <a href="/wiki/Davis_Cup" title="Davis Cup">Davis Cup</a> for <a href="/wiki/Switzerland_Davis_Cup_team" title="Switzerland Davis Cup team">Switzerland</a> debut in the <a href="/wiki/1999_Davis_Cup_World_Group#Switzerland_vs._Italy" title="1999 Davis Cup World Group">World Group 1st Round against Italy in 1999</a> at 17 years of age. In his first match he defeated <a href="/wiki/Davide_Sanguinetti" title="Davide Sanguinetti">Davide Sanguinetti</a> in four sets and recorded a second singles victory in a dead rubber two days later as Switzerland advanced to the World Group Quarterfinals. In the Quarterfinals Federer, who was still 17 years old, suffered his first Davis Cup loss when he was defeated by Belgian <a href="/wiki/Christophe_Van_Garsse" title="Christophe Van Garsse">Christophe Van Garsse</a> in five sets. The Swiss team went on to lose the rubber 3â2. A year later, Federer competed in his first Davis Cup doubles rubber where he teamed with countryman <a href="/wiki/Lorenzo_Manta" title="Lorenzo Manta">Lorenzo Manta</a> to defeat Australians <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Arthurs_(tennis)" title="Wayne Arthurs (tennis)">Wayne Arthurs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sandon_Stolle" title="Sandon Stolle">Sandon Stolle</a> in four sets. Despite the doubles victory, Federer lost both singles rubbers to <a href="/wiki/Mark_Philippoussis" title="Mark Philippoussis">Mark Philippoussis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt" title="Lleyton Hewitt">Lleyton Hewitt</a> which saw Switzerland sent to the World Group Playoffs for the first time in Federer's career. He returned for the playoffs in July 2000 and led Switzerland to a 5â0 win over <a href="/wiki/Belarus_Davis_Cup_team" title="Belarus Davis Cup team">Belarus</a> by recording wins in singles and doubles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>His first Davis Cup highlight came in 2003 as the newly crowned Wimbledon champion led his country to an historic semifinal run.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> After recording five wins in ties against the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_Davis_Cup_team" title="Netherlands Davis Cup team">Netherlands</a> and <a href="/wiki/France_Davis_Cup_team" title="France Davis Cup team">France</a>, the Swiss team traveled to Melbourne to play the highly rated <a href="/wiki/Australia_Davis_Cup_team" title="Australia Davis Cup team">Australians</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Federer once again defeated Wimbledon runner-up <a href="/wiki/Mark_Philippoussis" title="Mark Philippoussis">Mark Philippoussis</a> in the second rubber but allowed the Australians to lead the tie 2â1 going into Day 3 after dropping the doubles rubber in five sets.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Federer then played Lleyton Hewitt in a sudden death situation for Switzerland and despite leading two sets to love,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> succumbed to a fast finishing Hewitt in five sets.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Australia went on to claim the Davis Cup title months later<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> as Federer's interest in Davis Cup began to wane<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and his focus shifted to his personal career.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> He skipped many ties over the years but often competed in the World Group Playoffs in order for Switzerland to maintain their place in the top division.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The emergence of countryman <a href="/wiki/Stanislas_Wawrinka" class="mw-redirect" title="Stanislas Wawrinka">Stanislas Wawrinka</a> as a Grand Slam singles champion in 2014 renewed hope for Federer in his Davis Cup quest, and the pair both committed to playing each tie that year. Their commitment paid off as wins over <a href="/wiki/Serbia_Davis_Cup_team" title="Serbia Davis Cup team">Serbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan_Davis_Cup_team" title="Kazakhstan Davis Cup team">Kazakhstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italy_Davis_Cup_team" title="Italy Davis Cup team">Italy</a> allowed the Swiss team to advance to the <a href="/wiki/2014_Davis_Cup" title="2014 Davis Cup">2014 Davis Cup</a> Final. Leading into the final, Federer was suffering from a back injury<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> that threw serious doubt over Switzerland's chance to claim the title, and a second rubber straight sets loss to <a href="/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils" title="GaÃ«l Monfils">GaÃ«l Monfils</a> seemingly spelled the worst for Switzerland. However, a rejuvenated Federer returned the next day to help claim the doubles rubber, which set up a fourth rubber singles tie between Federer and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gasquet" title="Richard Gasquet">Richard Gasquet</a>. Federer defeated Gasquet in straight sets and in doing so handed Switzerland its first (and only to date) Davis Cup title.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer holds many Davis Cup records for Switzerland that includes most total wins, most singles wins and most years played.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Olympic_Games">Olympic Games</span></h3> 
      <p>An 18-year-old Federer made his <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Summer Olympics">Olympic</a> debut at <a href="/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics" title="2000 Summer Olympics">Sydney</a> in 2000, where he entered the singles competition. He surprised many by reaching the semifinals but lost to <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Haas" title="Tommy Haas">Tommy Haas</a> in the semifinals and then to <a href="/wiki/Arnaud_Di_Pasquale" title="Arnaud Di Pasquale">Arnaud Di Pasquale</a> in the bronze medal match, causing Federer to leave Sydney empty handed.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a>, Federer was the clear favorite after claiming the world No. 1 ranking earlier in the year and capturing the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> titles. However, he lost in the second round to 18-year-old TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych. In doubles, he and compatriot <a href="/wiki/Yves_Allegro" title="Yves Allegro">Yves Allegro</a> lost in the second round.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, Federer was again the top seed and favorite, but lost in the quarterfinals to <a href="/wiki/James_Blake_(tennis)" title="James Blake (tennis)">James Blake</a>. However, he found more success on the doubles court, capturing the gold medal in men's doubles with compatriot Stan Wawrinka, defeating <a href="/wiki/Simon_Aspelin" title="Simon Aspelin">Simon Aspelin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Johansson" title="Thomas Johansson">Thomas Johansson</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sweden_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics" title="Sweden at the 2008 Summer Olympics">Sweden</a>. At both the Athens and Beijing Olympic Games, Federer was the flagbearer for Switzerland in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_opening_ceremony" class="mw-redirect" title="Olympic opening ceremony">opening ceremony</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">London 2012</a>, Federer won his first singles medal, losing to <a href="/wiki/Andy_Murray" title="Andy Murray">Andy Murray</a> in the final to claim the silver. He and Wawrinka were unable to defend their gold medal in doubles, losing in the second round to <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Erlich" title="Jonathan Erlich">Jonathan Erlich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andy_Ram" title="Andy Ram">Andy Ram</a> of <a href="/wiki/Israel_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics" title="Israel at the 2012 Summer Olympics">Israel</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer did not compete in the <a href="/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics" title="2016 Summer Olympics">2016 Rio Olympics</a> after taking the rest of the season off after <a href="/wiki/2016_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2016 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a> to recover from a knee injury.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hopman_Cup">Hopman Cup</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer won the <a href="/wiki/2001_Hopman_Cup" title="2001 Hopman Cup">2001 Hopman Cup</a> representing Switzerland, along with <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a>. The duo defeated the American pair of <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jan-Michael_Gambill" title="Jan-Michael Gambill">Jan-Michael Gambill</a> in the finals.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> He also played the next year, along with his current wife <a href="/wiki/Mirka_Vavrinec" class="mw-redirect" title="Mirka Vavrinec">Mirka Vavrinec</a>, but they lost in the round robin stage.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer played again at the <a href="/wiki/Hopman_Cup" title="Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> in <a href="/wiki/2017_Hopman_Cup" title="2017 Hopman Cup">2017</a>, along with <a href="/wiki/Belinda_Bencic" title="Belinda Bencic">Belinda Bencic</a>. They won all of their ties except the last one, and as a result they couldn't make the final.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In 2018, Federer won his second <a href="/wiki/2018_Hopman_Cup" title="2018 Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> title and third overall for <a href="/wiki/Switzerland_at_the_Hopman_Cup" title="Switzerland at the Hopman Cup">Switzerland</a>. His partner was <a href="/wiki/Belinda_Bencic" title="Belinda Bencic">Belinda Bencic</a> again. The Swiss team won all the ties and Federer won all his singles and mixed doubles matches. They defeated the German pair, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Zverev" title="Alexander Zverev">Alexander Zverev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Angelique_Kerber" title="Angelique Kerber">Angelique Kerber</a>, in the final 2â1.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Federer won his third and second consecutive <a href="/wiki/2019_Hopman_Cup" title="2019 Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> title in 2019 alongside <a href="/wiki/Belinda_Bencic" title="Belinda Bencic">Belinda Bencic</a>. They again defeated <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Zverev" title="Alexander Zverev">Alexander Zverev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Angelique_Kerber" title="Angelique Kerber">Angelique Kerber</a> of <a href="/wiki/Germany_at_the_Hopman_Cup" title="Germany at the Hopman Cup">Germany</a> in the final, and won the final tie 2â1 by winning a tiebreak in the final set of the mixed doubles (5â4). Federer again won all of his singles matches. The Swiss team only lost one tie to <a href="/wiki/Greece_at_the_Hopman_Cup" title="Greece at the Hopman Cup">Greece</a> (1â2).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Roger Federer is the most successful individual in Hopman Cup (3 titles) history.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_representation">International representation</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Laver_Cup">Laver Cup</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer founded the <a href="/wiki/Laver_Cup" title="Laver Cup">Laver Cup</a>, which pits Europe against the rest of the world. The tournament is named in honor of <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a> and the inaugural edition was played in 2017.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Europe won the <a href="/wiki/2017_Laver_Cup" title="2017 Laver Cup">inaugural Laver Cup</a> in 2017. Federer played his first singles match on day two, when he dispatched Sam Querrey in straight sets. Later on day two, he partnered with his rival Nadal in doubles, where they defeated the Team World duo of Sam Querrey and Jack Sock in the match tie breaker, which took place at one set all. This was the first time Federer and Nadal competed on the same side of a doubles match. On day three, Federer competed in the final match of the tournament, where he sealed victory for Team Europe by defeating Nick Kyrgios in the champion's tiebreak (saving a match point). With three wins and seven points, Federer was the most accomplished player of the tournament.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/2018_Laver_Cup" title="2018 Laver Cup">second edition</a> was played in 2018. The European team led by Federer retained the title after defeating Team World, 13â8. Federer won both his singles matches, against Nick Kyrgios and John Isner, but lost both his doubles matches.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Rivalries">Rivalries</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: 
       <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis)" title="Big Four (tennis)">Big Four (tennis)</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Nadal">Federer vs. Nadal</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Federer%E2%80%93Nadal_rivalry" title="FedererâNadal rivalry">FedererâNadal rivalry</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:FedalWimbledon2008.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/FedalWimbledon2008.jpg/220px-FedalWimbledon2008.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/FedalWimbledon2008.jpg/330px-FedalWimbledon2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/FedalWimbledon2008.jpg/440px-FedalWimbledon2008.jpg 2x" data-file-width="476" data-file-height="317"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:FedalWimbledon2008.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer and Nadal ahead of the 2008 Wimbledon final
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a> have played 40 times, with Federer trailing 16â24. Federer has a winning record on grass 3â1 and hard courts 11â9, while Nadal leads on clay 14â2.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> Because tournament seedings are based on rankings, 24 of their matches have been in tournament finals which have included an all-time record nine Grand Slam finals.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Federer and Nadal have been playing each other since 2004, and their rivalry is a significant part of both men's careers.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> The latest encounter was at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2019 Wimbledon Championships</a>, where Federer won to reach the final. </p>
      <p>They held the top two rankings on the ATP Tour from July 2005 until 17 August 2009, when Nadal fell to No. 3 (Andy Murray became the new No. 2),<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> and again from 11 September 2017 until 15 October 2018 (Novak Djokovic became the new No. 2). They are the only pair of men to have ever finished six consecutive calendar years at the top. Federer was ranked No. 1 for a record 237 consecutive weeks beginning in February 2004. Nadal, who is five years younger, ascended to No. 2 in July 2005 and held this spot for 160 consecutive weeks, before surpassing Federer in August 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From 2006 to 2008, they played in every French Open and Wimbledon final. They then met in the <a href="/wiki/2009_Australian_Open" title="2009 Australian Open">2009 Australian Open</a> final, the <a href="/wiki/2011_French_Open" title="2011 French Open">2011 French Open</a> final, and the <a href="/wiki/2017_Australian_Open" title="2017 Australian Open">2017 Australian Open</a> final. Nadal won six of the nine, losing the first two Wimbledon finals and the second Australian Open final. Four of these finals were five set-matches (2007 and 2008 Wimbledon, 2009 and 2017 Australian Open), with the 2008 Wimbledon final being lauded as the greatest match ever by many long-time tennis analysts.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> Of their 40 meetings, 13 have reached a deciding set. They have also played in 12 <a href="/wiki/ATP_Masters_Series" title="ATP Masters Series">Masters Series</a> finals, including their lone five-hour match at the 2006 <a href="/wiki/Rome_Masters" class="mw-redirect" title="Rome Masters">Rome Masters</a> which Nadal won in a fifth-set tie-break, having saved two match points. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Djokovic">Federer vs. Djokovic</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Federer_rivalry" title="DjokovicâFederer rivalry">DjokovicâFederer rivalry</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_(20853473285).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_%2820853473285%29.jpg/220px-Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_%2820853473285%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_%2820853473285%29.jpg/330px-Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_%2820853473285%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_%2820853473285%29.jpg/440px-Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_%2820853473285%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cincinnati-Tennis-2015-ATP-WTA-148_(20853473285).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer and Djokovic, 
         <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters" title="Cincinnati Masters">Cincinnati Masters</a> final 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a> have played 48 times, with Federer trailing 22â26.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> They are tied 4â4 on clay while Federer trails 17â19 on hard-courts and 1â3 on grass. The FedererâDjokovic rivalry is the largest rivalry in men's Grand Slam tournament history with a record 16 matches played against each other. Djokovic is the only player besides Nadal to defeat Federer in consecutive Grand Slam tournaments (2010 US Open and 2011 Australian Open, also 2015 Wimbledon, US Open and 2016 Australian Open), and the only player besides Nadal and Murray who has double-figure career wins over Federer. Djokovic is one of two players (the other again being Nadal) on tour to have defeated Federer in straight sets at a Grand Slam event multiple times (2008 Australian Open, 2011 Australian Open, 2012 French Open), both the players have done so three times. Of their 48 meetings, 19 have reached a deciding set. </p>
      <p>Federer and Djokovic first played in a Grand Slam final at the <a href="/wiki/2007_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2007 US Open (tennis)">2007 US Open</a> where the three-time reigning champion and No. 1 Federer emerged victorious in straight sets. Federer ended Djokovic's perfect 41â0 start to the 2011 season in the semifinals of the French Open, but Djokovic was able to avenge this loss at the 2011 US Open in five sets after saving two match points against Federer for the second straight year.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> In the semifinals of Wimbledon 2012, Federer beat defending champion and No. 1 Djokovic in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> The two met again during the finals of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2014 Wimbledon Championships">2014 Wimbledon Championships</a> with Djokovic emerging victorious after five sets.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> Federer also ended Djokovic's 28 straight wins in China at <a href="/wiki/2014_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2014 Shanghai Rolex Masters â Singles">2014 Shanghai Open</a>. Federer and Djokovic rematched in the <a href="/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2015 Wimbledon Championships">2015 Wimbledon Championships</a> with Djokovic once again claiming victory in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> The pair met once more for the final major of the season, the <a href="/wiki/2015_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2015 US Open (tennis)">2015 US Open</a> and once more Djokovic prevailed in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2019 Wimbledon Championships">2019 Wimbledon Championships</a>, Djokovic bested Federer in an almost 5 hour match whose final set went to a tiebreak. This was the fifth consecutive time that Djokovic defeated Federer in Grand Slam matches. Some experts have included the rivalry between Federer and Djokovic as one of the best rivalries in the Open Era.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Murray">Federer vs. Murray</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/Andy_Murray" title="Andy Murray">Andy Murray</a> have played 25 times, with Federer leading 14â11. Federer leads 12â10 on hard courts, and 2â1 on grass. They have never met on clay.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> The two have met six times at the Grand Slam tournament level, the first three times in the finals, Federer winning all three of these matches; at the 2008 US Open<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> and the 2010 Australian Open,<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> both of which he won in straight sets, and at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles_final" class="mw-redirect" title="2012 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles final">2012 Wimbledon Championships</a> in which Murray took the opening set, but went on to lose in four sets. However, Murray won their encounter in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_Open" title="2013 Australian Open">2013 Australian Open</a>, defeating Federer for the first time at a Grand slam tournament in five sets. At the <a href="/wiki/2014_Australian_Open" title="2014 Australian Open">2014 Australian Open</a>, Federer reversed that result, defeating Murray in four sets in the quarterfinals.
