The most recent meeting between the two in a Major was in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2015 Wimbledon Championships">2015 Wimbledon Championships</a>, where a dominant Federer triumphed in straight sets. </p>
      <p>They met in the final of the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, in which Murray defeated Federer in straight sets, denying Federer a <a href="/wiki/Career_Golden_Slam" class="mw-redirect" title="Career Golden Slam">career Golden Slam</a>. Murray also leads 6â3 in ATP 1000 tournaments, 2â0 in finals. They have also met five times at the <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Finals">ATP World Tour Finals</a>, with Murray winning in Shanghai in 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> and Federer in London in 2009, 2010, 2012, and 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> Murray is one of only three players to have recorded ten or more victories over Federer (the other two being Nadal and <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Roddick">Federer vs. Roddick</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Federer%E2%80%93Roddick_rivalry" title="FedererâRoddick rivalry">FedererâRoddick rivalry</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/Andy_Roddick" title="Andy Roddick">Andy Roddick</a> played 24 times, and Federer leads their head-to-head 21â3. Roddick lost his No. 1 ranking to Federer after Federer won his first Australian Open in 2004. Their rivalry includes four Grand Slam event finals, three at Wimbledon and one at the US Open, all won by Federer.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> Roddick himself said it was not much of a rivalry, being so one-sided.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 2009 Wimbledon final, Roddick lost to Federer in five sets. The match included a 30-game fifth set (a Grand Slam final record) and lasted over four hours. In the final game of the deciding set, Roddick's serve was broken for the first time in the match. With that victory, Federer broke <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a>' record of 14 Grand Slam singles titles, and Roddick apologised to Sampras (who was in attendance) for not being able to stop Federer. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Hewitt">Federer vs. Hewitt</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt" title="Lleyton Hewitt">Lleyton Hewitt</a> have played 27 times, with Federer leading 18â9.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> Early in their careers, Hewitt dominated Federer, winning seven of their first nine meetings, including a victory from two sets down in the 2003 Davis Cup semifinal which allowed Australia to defeat Switzerland. This marked a turning point in the rivalry, as Federer won 16 of the next 18 meetings from 2004 onwards. This is Hewitt's longest rivalry as these two first played each other as juniors in 1996. They met in one Grand Slam tournament final, the <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">2004 US Open</a> final, where Federer won his first US Open title in a lopsided encounter in which Federer scored a bagel on both sides of a second-set tiebreak. Federer met Hewitt at six of the Grand Slam tournaments in which he lifted the trophy, including all five of his triumphs between 2004 and 2005. Their last meeting was at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Brisbane_International" title="2014 Brisbane International">2014 Brisbane International</a>, where Hewitt triumphed over Federer in three sets for his first title since 2010, when he also beat Federer to the <a href="/wiki/2010_Gerry_Weber_Open" title="2010 Gerry Weber Open">Halle</a> title. </p>
      <p>Hewitt and Federer teamed up in the men's doubles at Wimbledon in <a href="/wiki/1999_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles" title="1999 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Doubles">1999</a>. They lost in the third round to <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Bj%C3%B6rkman" title="Jonas BjÃ¶rkman">Jonas BjÃ¶rkman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pat_Rafter" title="Pat Rafter">Pat Rafter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Nalbandian">Federer vs. Nalbandian</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/David_Nalbandian" title="David Nalbandian">David Nalbandian</a> have played 19 times, with Federer leading 11â8.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/David_Nalbandian" title="David Nalbandian">David Nalbandian</a> was Federer's biggest rival in his early career. Nalbandian dominated early on, winning their first five matches from 2002 to 2003. Federer reversed this trend at the <a href="/wiki/2003_Tennis_Masters_Cup" title="2003 Tennis Masters Cup">2003 Masters Cup</a>, where he recorded his first victory, and went on to win 11 of their last 14 meetings. Federer leads 6â5 on hard courts, 1â0 on grass, and 3â1 on clay courts, while Nalbandian leads 2â1 on carpet. Notable meetings include Nalbandian's win in a fifth-set tiebreaker to win the <a href="/wiki/2005_Tennis_Masters_Cup" title="2005 Tennis Masters Cup">2005 Masters Cup</a>, and Federer's win in the <a href="/wiki/2006_French_Open" title="2006 French Open">2006 French Open</a> semifinals. They met each other six times in Grand Slam tournaments, with Federer leading 4â2. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Safin">Federer vs. Safin</span></h3> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Marat_Safin" title="Marat Safin">Marat Safin</a> and Federer played 12 times, with Federer leading 10â2.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> Federer and Safin turned pro within one year of each other, with Safin turning pro in 1997 and Federer in 1998. Federer leads 4â1 on hard courts, 3â0 on grass, and 3â0 on clay courts, while Safin leads 1â0 on carpet. Notable meetings include Federer's defeating Safin at the 2002 Hamburg Masters to win the first Masters 1000 title of his career, as well as Federer's emerging victorious in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2004_Tennis_Masters_Cup" title="2004 Tennis Masters Cup">2004 Tennis Masters Cup</a>, after winning a tiebreak 20â18 on his eighth match point. Federer also defeated Safin in the finals of the <a href="/wiki/2004_Australian_Open" title="2004 Australian Open">2004 Australian Open</a> to capture his first Australian Open and second Grand Slam tournament title. However, Safin defeated Federer in the <a href="/wiki/2005_Australian_Open" title="2005 Australian Open">2005 Australian Open</a> semifinals, having saved one match point in the fourth-set tiebreak, to end a 26-match winning streak by Federer.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> They met each other five times in Grand Slam tournaments, with Federer leading 4â1. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Agassi">Federer vs. Agassi</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a> played 11 times, and Federer leads their head-to-head 8â3.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup> This was Federer's most significant rivalry with a dominant player of the previous generation. They first met in only the third tournament of Federer's career at the 1998 <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a> in Federer's hometown, with <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a> prevailing over the 17-year-old. Agassi also defeated Federer at the 2001 US Open and the finals of the Miami Masters in 2002. Federer began to turn the tide at the Masters Cup in 2003, when he defeated Agassi in both the round robin and the final. They played a memorable quarterfinal match at the <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">2004 US Open</a> that spanned over two days, with Federer eventually prevailing in five sets. At the <a href="/wiki/2005_Dubai_Tennis_Championships" title="2005 Dubai Tennis Championships">2005 Dubai Championships</a>, Federer and Agassi attracted worldwide headlines with a publicity stunt that saw the two men play on a helipad almost 220 meters above sea level at the hotel <a href="/wiki/Burj_al-Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Burj al-Arab">Burj al-Arab</a>. Their final match was at one of the most prestigious platforms in the sport, when they played in the finals of the <a href="/wiki/2005_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2005 US Open (tennis)">2005 US Open</a>. Federer was victorious in four sets, claiming the 6th Grand Slam tournament of his career and denying Agassi his 9th. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Wawrinka">Federer vs. Wawrinka</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer and his fellow <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Swiss</a> player <a href="/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka" title="Stan Wawrinka">Stan Wawrinka</a> have played each other 26 times, with Federer leading 23â3. Federer leads 7â1 in Grand Slam tournaments, 17â0 on hard courts, 1â0 on grass courts and 5â3 on clay courts. The pair are 1â1 in finals. Their first meeting in a final came at <a href="/wiki/2014_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters" title="2014 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters">2014 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters</a> where Wawrinka defeated Federer in three sets to win his first Masters 1000 title before Federer avenged his loss at the <a href="/wiki/2017_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2017 BNP Paribas Open">2017 BNP Paribas Open</a> by beating him in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> While the rivalry is one-sided in Federer's favour, the two have contested some close matches. Wawrinka defeated Federer in straight sets during the <a href="/wiki/2015_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2015 French Open â Men's Singles">2015 French Open</a> quarterfinals en route to winning his first French Open title, although Federer then won a straight-sets victory in the <a href="/wiki/2015_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2015 US Open â Men's Singles">2015 US Open</a> semifinals. Other close matches include the <a href="/wiki/2012_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2012 Shanghai Rolex Masters â Singles">2012 Shanghai Masters</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2013_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2013 BNP Paribas Open â Men's Singles">2013 Indian Wells Masters</a>, both of which Federer won in three sets, the <a href="/wiki/2014_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2014 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2014 Wimbledon</a> quarterfinal, which Federer won in four sets, the <a href="/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2014 ATP World Tour Finals â Singles">2014 ATP World Tour Final</a> semifinal, which Federer won in three sets after saving four match points, and the <a href="/wiki/2017_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2017 Australian Open</a> semifinal, which Federer won in five sets. Despite their on-court rivalry, they are friends off court,<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> and they have played doubles together on numerous occasions,<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> most notably when they won the doubles Olympic Gold at the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_doubles" title="Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics â Men's doubles">2008 Beijing Olympics</a> and when winning the <a href="/wiki/2014_Davis_Cup" title="2014 Davis Cup">2014 Davis Cup</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._del_Potro">Federer vs. del Potro</span></h3> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro" title="Juan MartÃ­n del Potro">Juan MartÃ­n del Potro</a> and Roger Federer have played 25 times, with Federer leading 18â7.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> They have met seven times in Grand Slam tournaments, with Federer leading 5â2. Their two most famous Grand Slam tournament meetings came in 2009. The first was in the <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a> semifinals, when Federer survived a five-set clash when he was on his way to the only French title of his career. The second was in the final of the <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, where del Potro beat five-time defending champion Federer in five sets, ending his 20-match winning streak at Grand Slams. Another high-profile match was in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles" title="Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics â Men's singles">2012 London Olympics</a>, where Federer prevailed 19â17 in the final set to secure the Olympic silver medal. They also met in the finals of the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Indoors" title="Swiss Indoors">Swiss Indoors</a> in 2012, 2013 and 2017, with del Potro prevailing on first two occasions, and Federer on last one of them in tight three-set matches. </p>
      <p>In the 2017 U.S. Open quarterfinals, in a rematch of the 2009 US Open final, Del Potro again beat Federer in four sets to end his unbeaten streak in grand slams that year. With this win, Del Potro also denied the first Federer-Nadal match at US Open, as in 2009 where he beat Nadal in straight sets in the semifinals. Federer, however avenged this loss at the Shanghai Masters semifinals, where he beat del Potro in three sets after coming from a set down. In the final at the <a href="/wiki/2018_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2018 BNP Paribas Open">2018 BNP Paribas Open</a> del Potro beat Federer in three close sets, after facing match points in the third set. With this win del Potro won his first Masters 1000 title of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Berdych">Federer vs. Berdych</span></h3> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych" title="TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych">TomÃ¡Å¡ Berdych</a> and Federer have played 26 times, with Federer leading 20â6.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> Federer leads 12â5 on hard courts, 3â1 on grass courts, 4â0 on clay courts, and 1â0 on carpet. Berdych won their first professional match, notably upsetting then-No. 1 Federer at the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles" title="Tennis at the 2004 Summer Olympics â Men's singles">2004 Summer Olympics</a>. Federer then went on to win their next eight meetings, before Berdych ended the losing streak in 2010. Between 2010 and 2013, Berdych won 5 of 8 meetings. Federer again took lead of the matchup after he switched to a larger racquet in 2014, leading 9â0 since then. They have met ten times in Grand Slam tournaments, with Federer leading 8â2, and Berdych is one of five players, along with <a href="/wiki/Arnaud_Cl%C3%A9ment" title="Arnaud ClÃ©ment">Arnaud ClÃ©ment</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lex_Corretja" class="mw-redirect" title="Ãlex Corretja">Ãlex Corretja</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Nalbandian" title="David Nalbandian">David Nalbandian</a>, and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, to defeat Federer multiple times in majors before the semifinal stage. Their most notable Grand Slam matches took place in the <a href="/wiki/2009_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2009 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2009 Australian Open</a>, when Federer prevailed in five sets after dropping the first two sets, the <a href="/wiki/2010_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2010 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2010 Wimbledon Championships</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2012 US Open â Men's Singles">2012 US Open</a>, both of which Berdych won in four sets. Berdych went on to reach the only Grand Slam final of his career after the Wimbledon quarterfinal victory, ending Federer's run of seven consecutive finals at Wimbledon dating back to 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._Tsonga">Federer vs. Tsonga</span></h3> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga" title="Jo-Wilfried Tsonga">Jo-Wilfried Tsonga</a> and Federer have played 18 times, with Federer leading 12â6. Federer leads 5â3 on outdoor hard courts and 4â0 on indoor hard. They are 1â1 on grass and 2â2 on clay courts.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> The pair have met six times in Grand Slam tournaments, including their five-set matches in the quarterfinals of <a href="/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2011 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2011 Wimbledon</a> and <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2013 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2013 Australian Open</a>. They have also one Grand Slam semifinal meeting in the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2010 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2010 Australian Open</a>, with Federer winning in straight sets. Federer and Tsonga have played in the <a href="/wiki/2011_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2011 ATP World Tour Finals â Singles">2011 ATP World Tour Finals</a> final, with Federer winning his record-sixth <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Finals">Year-End Championship</a> in three sets. The pair have also met in two <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Masters 1000">ATP World Tour Masters 1000</a> finals. The first was in the <a href="/wiki/2011_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2011 BNP Paribas Masters â Singles">2011 BNP Paribas Masters</a>, with Federer winning his first title in Bercy, and the second was in the <a href="/wiki/2014_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2014 Rogers Cup â Men's Singles">2014 Rogers Cup</a>, with Tsonga winning his second Masters 1000 title. </p> 
      <h3><span id="Federer_vs._.C4.8Cili.C4.87"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Federer_vs._ÄiliÄ">Federer vs. ÄiliÄ</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer and <a href="/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87" title="Marin ÄiliÄ">Marin ÄiliÄ</a> have played 10 times, with Federer leading 9â1.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> ÄiliÄ's only victory came in the <a href="/wiki/2014_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2014 US Open â Men's Singles">2014 US Open semifinals</a>, after which he went on to win the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam title</a>. Their first encounter was in the 3rd round in the <a href="/wiki/2008_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2008 BNP Paribas Masters â Singles">2008 Paris Masters</a>, which Federer won in straight sets. They have played five Grand Slam matches, two in <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a>, two in the US Open, and one at the <a href="/wiki/2018_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2018 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2018 Australian Open</a>; Federer leads these matches 4â1. Two of these have been Grand Slam finals â the <a href="/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2017 Wimbledon</a> final, which Federer won in straight sets, and the <a href="/wiki/2018_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2018 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2018 Australian Open</a> final, which Federer won in five sets. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Achievements">Achievements</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Roger_Federer" title="List of career achievements by Roger Federer">List of career achievements by Roger Federer</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Roger_Federer_(18566686046).jpg" class="image"><img alt="A tennis player holds a racket in his hand" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Roger_Federer_%2818566686046%29.jpg/250px-Roger_Federer_%2818566686046%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Roger_Federer_%2818566686046%29.jpg/375px-Roger_Federer_%2818566686046%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Roger_Federer_%2818566686046%29.jpg/500px-Roger_Federer_%2818566686046%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3503" data-file-height="2933"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Roger_Federer_(18566686046).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Roger Federer has spent a total of 310 weeks and 237 consecutive weeks at the top of the 
         <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals" title="Association of Tennis Professionals">ATP rankings</a>, the most of any player.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>He dominated the game at his peak and has won more Grand Slam tournament titles (20) than any other men's singles player.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> He is also the first men's singles player to have reached ten consecutive Grand Slam tournament finals and a total of 31 Grand Slam finals.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> He has earned a men's doubles gold medal, and a men's single silver medal at the Olympics in 2008 and 2012, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> He has spent the most amount of time in the Open Era at the top of the <a href="/wiki/ATP_Rankings" title="ATP Rankings">ATP Rankings</a> (310 weeks). He also holds the record for the most titles (6) at the year-end tournament, where only the year-end eight highest-ranked players participate. Federer was ranked among the top eight players in the world continuously for 14 years and two weeksâfrom 14 October 2002 until 31 October 2016, when <a href="/wiki/2016_Roger_Federer_tennis_season" title="2016 Roger Federer tennis season">injuries forced him to skip</a> much of the 2016 season.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer has won the <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Awards#Player_of_the_year" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Awards">ATP Player of the Year</a> five times (2004â07, 2009), and has become <a href="/wiki/ITF_World_Champion" class="mw-redirect" title="ITF World Champion">ITF World Champion</a> five times (2004â07, 2009). He has won the <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Awards#ATPWorldTour.com_Fans'_Favorite" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Awards">ATPWorldTour.com Fans' Favourite Award</a> a record 16 times consecutively (2003â18), and has won the <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Awards#Stefan_Edberg_Sportsmanship_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Awards">Stefan Edberg Sportsmanship Award</a> (voted for by the players) a record 13 times (2004â09, 2011â17),<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> both being awards indicative of respect and popularity. He also won the <a href="/wiki/ATP_Arthur_Ashe_Humanitarian_award" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP Arthur Ashe Humanitarian award">Arthur Ashe Humanitarian of the Year Award</a> twice (2006, 2013), the <a href="/wiki/Laureus_World_Sports_Award_for_Sportsman_of_the_Year" title="Laureus World Sports Award for Sportsman of the Year">Laureus World Sportsman of the Year</a> five times (2005â08, 2018), and the <a href="/wiki/Laureus_World_Sports_Award_for_Comeback_of_the_Year" title="Laureus World Sports Award for Comeback of the Year">Laureus World Comeback of the Year</a> once, following his 2017 renaissance.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer is one of the founders, via his management company TEAM8, of the <a href="/wiki/Laver_Cup" title="Laver Cup">Laver Cup</a>; the annual team tennis tournament which pits Europe against the rest of the world. He co-founded the tournament in honor of tennis legend <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a> and the inaugural edition was played in 2017. </p>
      <p>In 2018, Federer returned to the Australian Open to defend his 2017 title and won his 20th Grand Slam tournament. Rafael Nadal, with his 2019 US Open win, sits one behind Roger. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy_and_cultural_impact">Legacy and cultural impact</span></h2> 
      <p>Roger Federer has huge popularity in the world of sport, to the point that he has been called a <a href="/wiki/Living_legend_(person)" title="Living legend (person)">living legend</a> in his own time.<sup id="cite_ref-legend1_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legend1-251">[251]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-legend2_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legend2-252">[252]</a></sup> Given his achievements, Federer is widely considered to be one of the greatest tennis players of all time, with many players and analysts considering him to be the greatest tennis player of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[a]</a></sup> He has also been called the greatest athlete of his generation.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tennis.com" class="mw-redirect" title="Tennis.com">Tennis.com</a> listed him as the greatest male player of the open era.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>No other male tennis player has won 20 major singles titles in the Open Era, and he has been in 31 major finals, including 10 in a row. He has held the world No. 1 spot in the ATP rankings for longer than any other male player. He was ranked No. 1 at the age of 36 and has won a record eight Wimbledon titles. He won five consecutive US Open titles, which is the most in the Open Era. </p>
      <p>He has been voted by his peers to receive the tour <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Awards#Stefan_Edberg_Sportsmanship_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Awards">Sportsmanship Award</a> a record thirteen times and voted by tennis fans to receive the <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Awards#ATPWorldTour.com_Fans'_Favorite" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour Awards">ATP Fans' Favorite</a> award for fifteen consecutive years.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[270]</a></sup> Federer has been named the Swiss Sports Personality of the Year a record seven times. He has been named the ATP Player of the Year and ITF World Champion five times, and he has won the Laureus World Sportsman of the Year award a record five times, including four consecutive awards from 2005 to 2008. He is also the only individual to have won the BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year award four times. </p>
      <p>Federer helped to lead a revival in tennis known by many as the <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis)" title="Big Four (tennis)">Golden Age</a>. This led to increased interest in the sport, which in turn led to higher revenues for many venues across tennis. During this period rising revenues led to exploding prize money; when Federer first won the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a> in 2004 he earned $985,000, compared to when he won in 2018 and the prize had increased to AUD 4<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Upon winning the <a href="/wiki/2009_French_Open" title="2009 French Open">2009 French Open</a> and completing the career Grand Slam, Federer became the first individual male tennis player to grace the cover of <a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated" title="Sports Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a> since <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a> in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup> He was also the first non-American player to appear on the cover of the magazine since <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Edberg" title="Stefan Edberg">Stefan Edberg</a> in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-sicovers.com_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sicovers.com-274">[273]</a></sup> Federer again made the cover of <i>Sports Illustrated</i> following his record-breaking <a href="/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">8th Wimbledon title</a> and second Grand Slam of 2017, becoming the first male tennis player to be featured on the cover since himself in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-sicovers.com_274-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sicovers.com-274">[273]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Playing_style">Playing style</span></h2> 
      <p>Federer's versatility has been described by <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Connors" title="Jimmy Connors">Jimmy Connors</a> as: "In an era of specialists, you're either a clay court specialist, a grass court specialist, or a hard court specialist... or you're Roger Federer."<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Dominik_Hrbaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Dominik Hrbaty">Dominik Hrbaty</a> described what it was like to play Federer in the Scoop Malinowski book "Facing Federer": âRoger is different. Heâs the new generation. He was comparable to <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Rios" class="mw-redirect" title="Marcelo Rios">Marcelo Rios</a>, very talented, he has great hands, but the difference was Roger had the big serve, big return. He could make winners out of anything basically. And even out of defense. And Roger is just one of a kind." <sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg/220px-The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="415" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg/330px-The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg/440px-The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="848" data-file-height="1600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Federer_Technique_-_Oz_Open_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Federer serving at the 
         <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a> in 2014
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>An elite athlete, Federer is an <a href="/wiki/Tennis_strategy#All-court_player" title="Tennis strategy">all-court, all-around player</a> known for his speed, fluid style of play, and exceptional shot making. Federer mainly plays from the baseline but is also comfortable at the net, being one of the best volleyers in the game.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup> He has a powerful, accurate <a href="/wiki/Smash_(tennis)" title="Smash (tennis)">smash</a> and very effectively performs rare elements of professional tennis, such as the backhand smash and <a href="/wiki/Skyhook_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="Skyhook (tennis)">skyhook</a>, half-volley, jump smash (slam dunk) and an aggressive serve return known affectionately as SABR (Sneak Attack By Roger, a half-volley attack on an opponent's second serve). <a href="/wiki/David_Foster_Wallace" title="David Foster Wallace">David Foster Wallace</a> compared the brute force of Federer's forehand motion with that of "a great liquid whip",<sup id="cite_ref-Wallace_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wallace-4">[4]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/John_McEnroe" title="John McEnroe">John McEnroe</a> has referred to Federer's forehand as "the greatest shot in our sport."<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[277]</a></sup> Federer is also known for his efficient, deceptively effortless movement around the court and excellent footwork, which enables him to run around shots directed to his backhand, usually considered his weaker wing, and instead hit a powerful and penetrating inside-out or inside-in forehand, one of his best shots. He also has great variety with his forehand, able to hit with topspin or pace (or both), thus opening up the court and going in to the forecourt for aggressive volleys. </p>
      <p>Federer plays with a single-handed backhand, which gives him great variety. He employs the <a href="/wiki/Backspin" title="Backspin">slice</a>, occasionally using it to lure his opponent to the net and deliver a passing shot. Federer can also fire <a href="/wiki/Topspin" title="Topspin">topspin</a> winners and possesses a 'flick' backhand with which he can generate pace with his wrist; this is usually used to pass the opponent at the net.<sup id="cite_ref-Wallace_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wallace-4">[4]</a></sup> He has averaged 90% of service games won throughout his career, oftentimes coming up victorious in clutch or pressure service games. His <a href="/wiki/Serve_(tennis)" title="Serve (tennis)">serve</a> is difficult to read because he always uses a similar ball toss, regardless of what type of serve he is going to hit and where he aims to hit it, and turns his back to his opponents during his motion. He is often able to produce big serves on key points during a match. His first serve is typically around 200<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>km/h (125<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>mph);<sup id="cite_ref-AUSServe_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AUSServe-279">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WIMBYServe_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WIMBYServe-280">[279]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup> however, he is capable of serving at 220<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>km/h (137<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>mph).<sup id="cite_ref-AUSServe_279-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AUSServe-279">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WIMBYServe_280-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WIMBYServe-280">[279]</a></sup> Federer is also accomplished at <a href="/wiki/Serve_and_volley" title="Serve and volley">serve and volleying</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup> and employed this tactic frequently in his early career.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Later in his career, Federer added the drop shot to his arsenal and can perform a well-disguised one off both wings. He sometimes uses a between-the-legs shot, which is colloquially referred to as a "<a href="/wiki/Tweener_(tennis)" title="Tweener (tennis)">tweener</a>" or "hotdog". His most notable use of the tweener was in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2009_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2009 US Open (tennis)">2009 US Open</a> against <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>, bringing him triple match point.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> Federer is one of the top players who employ successfully the "squash shot", when he gets pushed deep and wide on his forehand wing. Since <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Edberg" title="Stefan Edberg">Stefan Edberg</a> joined his coaching team at the start of the 2014 season, Federer has played a more offensive game, attacking the net more often, and improved his volley shots.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup> In the lead-up to the 2015 US Open, Federer successfully added a new unique shot to his arsenal called SABR (Sneak Attack by Roger), in which he charges forward to receive the second serve and hits a return on the service line. The SABR is a unique shot that Federer owns, in the way that he manages to add enough power and placement into the shot, which makes it very difficult, or close to impossible for the opponent to reach it.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup> With the switch to a bigger 97 inch racket from 90 inches, Federer has gained easy power while relinquishing some control on his shots. The bigger racket has enabled easier serving and better defense on both wings with fewer shanks. However this has diminished control and power on his forehand, slice backhand and dropshot.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[288]</a></sup> Since his comeback in 2017, Federer is noted for his improved backhand both down the line and cross court which was cited as the reason for his win against Nadal in the 2017 Australian Open Final and Indian Wells 4th round. </p>
      <p>Federer is also noted for his cool demeanour and emotional control on the court. In contrast to his early career, most of his professional game has been characterised by lack of outbursts or emotional frustration at errors, which gives him an advantage over less controlled opponents.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer declared: </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>I don't get the anxiety during a match so much anymore. You know, to throw racquets, to toss balls out of the court, scream and stuff. I almost laugh [on the inside] about it a little bit today when an opponent does it. But that's something for me that's not a problem any more.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup> </p>
      </blockquote> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Equipment_and_apparel">Equipment and apparel</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Equipment">Equipment</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer plays with his signature <a href="/wiki/Wilson_Sporting_Goods" title="Wilson Sporting Goods">Wilson</a> Pro Staff RF97 Autograph racquet. It has a 97 square inch head, 16x19 string pattern, 366 gram strung weight, 340 gram swing weight, 68 RA stiffness, and 9 point head light balance.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> Federer <a href="/wiki/Strings_(tennis)" title="Strings (tennis)">strings</a> his racquets using Wilson <a href="/wiki/Strings_(tennis)#Natural_Gut" title="Strings (tennis)">Natural Gut</a> 16 gauge for his main strings and Luxilon Big Banger ALU Power Rough 16L gauge (<a href="/wiki/Strings_(tennis)#Polyester" title="Strings (tennis)">polyester</a>) for his cross strings. In an interview in November 2017, Federer stated his favorite stringing tension is 26.5 kilograms (58.4&nbsp;lb) mains &amp; 25 kilograms (55.1&nbsp;lb) crosses.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As a junior player, Federer played with a Wilson Pro Staff 6.0 85 square inch head racquet. He switched to a bigger custom-built Wilson 90 square inch head racquet in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[295]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup> His grip size was â<span class="frac nowrap">4<span class="visualhide">&nbsp;</span><sup>3</sup>â<sub>8</sub></span><span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>inches (L3).<sup id="cite_ref-Ask_Roger_Equipment_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ask_Roger_Equipment-298">[297]</a></sup> When asked about string tensions, Federer stated "this depends on how warm the days are and with what kind of balls I play and against who I play. So you can see<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>â it depends on several factors and not just the surface; the feeling I have is most important."<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Apparel">Apparel</span></h3> 
      <p>Federer first signed with <a href="/wiki/Nike,_Inc." title="Nike, Inc.">Nike</a> footwear and apparel in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup> For the 2006 championships at Wimbledon, Nike designed a jacket emblazoned with a crest of three tennis racquets, symbolising the three Wimbledon Championships he had previously won, and which was updated the next year with four racquets after he won the Championship in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup> At Wimbledon 2008, and again in 2009, Nike continued this trend by making him a personalised cardigan that also had his own logo, an R and an F joined together,<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[301]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup> which originally was designed by his wife <a href="/wiki/Mirka_Federer" title="Mirka Federer">Mirka Vavrinec</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Federer's contract with <a href="/wiki/Nike,_Inc." title="Nike, Inc.">Nike</a> expired in March 2018, and he later signed a deal with <a href="/wiki/Uniqlo" title="Uniqlo">Uniqlo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-uniqlo_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uniqlo-305">[304]</a></sup> It was reported that <a href="/wiki/Uniqlo" title="Uniqlo">Uniqlo</a> signed Federer for roughly $300<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million for 10 years ($30<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million per year), as opposed to Nike's previous deal with Federer which was roughly $10<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million per year.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup> However, Federer doesn't have a shoe deal and still chooses to wear <a href="/wiki/Nike,_Inc." title="Nike, Inc.">Nike</a> trainers.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Endorsements">Endorsements</span></h2> 
      <p>Federer is one of the highest-earning athletes in the world. As of June 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Roger_Federer&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, he is listed at <abbr title="Number">#</abbr>5 on the <a href="/wiki/Forbes%27_list_of_world%27s_highest-paid_athletes" class="mw-redirect" title="Forbes' list of world's highest-paid athletes">Forbes "World's Highest Paid Athletes" list</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pr_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pr-308">[307]</a></sup> He is endorsed by Japanese clothing company <a href="/wiki/Uniqlo" title="Uniqlo">Uniqlo</a><sup id="cite_ref-uniqlo_305-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uniqlo-305">[304]</a></sup> and Swiss companies <a href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationale_Suisse" class="extiw" title="de:Nationale Suisse">Nationale Suisse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Credit_Suisse" title="Credit Suisse">Credit Suisse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rolex" title="Rolex">Rolex</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lindt" class="mw-redirect" title="Lindt">Lindt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunrise_Communications_AG" title="Sunrise Communications AG">Sunrise</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jura_Elektroapparate" title="Jura Elektroapparate">Jura Elektroapparate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup> In 2010, his endorsement by <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> China was extended into a global partnership deal.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> His other sponsors include <a href="/wiki/Gillette_(brand)" class="mw-redirect" title="Gillette (brand)">Gillette</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wilson_Sporting_Goods" title="Wilson Sporting Goods">Wilson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barilla_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Barilla Group">Barilla</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mo%C3%ABt_%26_Chandon" title="MoÃ«t &amp; Chandon">MoÃ«t &amp; Chandon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pr_308-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pr-308">[307]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup> Previously, he was an ambassador for <a href="/wiki/Nike,_Inc." title="Nike, Inc.">Nike</a>, <a href="/wiki/NetJets" title="NetJets">NetJets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emmi_AG" title="Emmi AG">Emmi AG</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> and for <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Lacroix" title="Maurice Lacroix">Maurice Lacroix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career_statistics">Career statistics</span></h2>

      </div>

      <p><small><b>Note:</b> <i>Federer received fourth-round walkovers at the US Open (2004 and 2012) and the Wimbledon Championships (2007), and a second-round walkover at the Australian Open (2012); these are not counted as wins</i></small> </p>

         <td><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain"><img alt="Spain" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a></span> Rafael Nadal</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/2017_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final" title="2017 Australian Open â Men's singles final">6â4, 3â6, 6â1, 3â6, 6â3</a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="background:#cfc;">

      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Guinness_World_Records">Guinness World Records</span></h4> 
      <p>As of 2019 Federer holds the third highest number of Guinness World Records within one discipline, a total of <a href="/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Roger_Federer#Guinness_World_Records" title="List of career achievements by Roger Federer">30, which include 18 performance based records</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[326]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Open_Era_records">Open Era records</span></h4> 
      <ul>
       <li>These records were attained in the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_Records_Open_Era_(Singles_Men)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tennis Records Open Era (Singles Men)">Open Era</a> of tennis.</li> 
       <li>Records in <b>bold</b> indicate peerless achievements.</li> 
       <li>Records in <i>italics</i> are active streaks.</li>
      </ul> 
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed"> 
       <tbody>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-267"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-267">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See:<sup id="cite_ref-tcgoat_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tcgoat-253">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lavergoat_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lavergoat-254">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-petegoat_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-petegoat-257">[257]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-aggoat_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aggoat-260">[260]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2017cement_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2017cement-261">[261]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2016top20_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2016top20-264">[264]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hwgoat_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hwgoat-265">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> See also: <i><a href="/wiki/100_Greatest_of_All_Time" title="100 Greatest of All Time">100 Greatest of All Time</a></i>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-336"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-336">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The existing Major champions Federer defeated were <a href="/wiki/Marat_Safin" title="Marat Safin">Marat Safin</a> (<a href="/wiki/2004_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2004 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2004 Australian Open</a>), <a href="/wiki/Andy_Roddick" title="Andy Roddick">Andy Roddick</a> (<a href="/wiki/2004_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2004 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2004</a>, <a href="/wiki/2005_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2005 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2005</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/2009_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2009 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2009</a> Wimbledon and <a href="/wiki/2006_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2006 US Open â Men's Singles">2006 US Open</a>), <a href="/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt" title="Lleyton Hewitt">Lleyton Hewitt</a> (<a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2004 US Open â Men's Singles">2004 US Open</a>), <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a> (<a href="/wiki/2005_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2005 US Open â Men's Singles">2005 US Open</a>), <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a> (<a href="/wiki/2006_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2006 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2006</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/2007_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2007 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2007</a> Wimbledon and <a href="/wiki/2017_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2017 Australian Open</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87" title="Marin ÄiliÄ">Marin ÄiliÄ</a> (<a href="/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 Wimbledon Championships â Men's Singles">2017 Wimbledon</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2018 Australian Open â Men's Singles">2018 Australian Open</a>).</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-YEC-353"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-YEC_353-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Known as "Tennis Masters Cup" (2000â2008), "ATP World Tour Finals" (2009â2016) and "<a href="/wiki/ATP_Finals" title="ATP Finals">ATP Finals</a>" (2017âpresent).</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>

       <li><span class="official-website"><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.rogerfederer.com/">Official website</a></span></span></li>
      </ul>

                <td style="width:30%;" rowspan="1">Preceded&nbsp;by<br><span style="font-weight: bold"><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States"><img alt="United States" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1235" data-file-height="650"></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a> <br> <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia"><img alt="Serbia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="945" data-file-height="630"></a></span> <b>Novak Djokovic</b></span> </td> 
                <td style="width: 40%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1"><b> <a href="/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_records" class="mw-redirect" title="ATP World Tour records">ATP Prize money leader</a></b><br>2007â2016 <br> 2017â2018 </td> 
                <td style="width: 30%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1">Succeeded&nbsp;by<br><span style="font-weight: bold"><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia"><img alt="Serbia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="945" data-file-height="630"></a></span> Novak Djokovic<br><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia"><img alt="Serbia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="945" data-file-height="630"></a></span> Novak Djokovic</span> </td>
               </tr> 
               <tr style="text-align:center;"> 
                <td style="width:30%;" rowspan="1">Preceded&nbsp;by<br><span style="font-weight: bold"><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States"><img alt="United States" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1235" data-file-height="650"></a></span> Pete Sampras</span> </td> 
                <td style="width: 40%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1"><b> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_related_tennis_records" title="List of Grand Slam related tennis records">Most career Grand Slam singles titles</a></b><br>July 5, 2009 â </td> 
                <td style="width: 30%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1"><b>Incumbent</b> </td>
               </tr> 
               <tr style="text-align:center;"> 
                <td style="width:30%;" rowspan="1">Preceded&nbsp;by<br><span style="font-weight: bold"><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States"><img alt="United States" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1235" data-file-height="650"></a></span> Pete Sampras</span> </td>

                   <li>2014 <a href="/wiki/Noah_Rubin_(tennis)" title="Noah Rubin (tennis)">Noah Rubin</a></li> 
                   <li>2015 <a href="/wiki/Reilly_Opelka" title="Reilly Opelka">Reilly Opelka</a></li> 
                   <li>2016 <a href="/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov" title="Denis Shapovalov">Denis Shapovalov</a></li> 
                   <li>2017 <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Davidovich_Fokina" title="Alejandro Davidovich Fokina">Alejandro Davidovich Fokina</a></li> 
                   <li>2018 <a href="/wiki/Tseng_Chun-hsin" title="Tseng Chun-hsin">Tseng Chun-hsin</a></li> 
                   <li>2019 <a href="/wiki/Shintaro_Mochizuki" title="Shintaro Mochizuki">Shintaro Mochizuki</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
              </tbody>
             </table>
            </div>

                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1955_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1955 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1955</a>) <a href="/wiki/Ken_Rosewall" title="Ken Rosewall">Ken Rosewall</a></li>

                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1957_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1957 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1957</a>) <a href="/wiki/Ashley_Cooper_(tennis)" title="Ashley Cooper (tennis)">Ashley Cooper</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1958_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1958 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1958</a>) <a href="/wiki/Ashley_Cooper_(tennis)" title="Ashley Cooper (tennis)">Ashley Cooper</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1959_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1959 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1959</a>) <a href="/wiki/Alex_Olmedo" title="Alex Olmedo">Alex Olmedo</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1960_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1960 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1960</a>) <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1961_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1961 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1961</a>) <a href="/wiki/Roy_Emerson" title="Roy Emerson">Roy Emerson</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1962_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1962 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1962</a>) <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/1963_Australian_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1963 Australian Championships â Men's Singles">1963</a>) <a href="/wiki/Roy_Emerson" title="Roy Emerson">Roy Emerson</a></li>

                       <li>(<a href="/wiki/1928_French_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1928 French Championships â Men's Singles">1928</a>) <a href="/wiki/Henri_Cochet" title="Henri Cochet">Henri Cochet</a></li>

                       <li>(<a href="/wiki/1930_French_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1930 French Championships â Men's Singles">1930</a>) <a href="/wiki/Henri_Cochet" title="Henri Cochet">Henri Cochet</a></li> 
                       <li>(<a href="/wiki/1931_French_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1931 French Championships â Men's Singles">1931</a>) <a href="/wiki/Jean_Borotra" title="Jean Borotra">Jean Borotra</a></li> 
                       <li>(<a href="/wiki/1932_French_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1932 French Championships â Men's Singles">1932</a>) <a href="/wiki/Henri_Cochet" title="Henri Cochet">Henri Cochet</a></li> 
                       <li>(<a href="/wiki/1933_French_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1933 French Championships â Men's Singles">1933</a>) <a href="/wiki/Jack_Crawford_(tennis)" title="Jack Crawford (tennis)">Jack Crawford</a></li> 
                       <li>(<a href="/wiki/1934_French_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="1934 French Championships â Men's Singles">1934</a>) <a href="/wiki/Gottfried_von_Cramm" title="Gottfried von Cramm">Gottfried von Cramm</a></li>

                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2005_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2005 US Open â Men's Singles">2005</a>) <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Roger Federer</a></li>

                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2007_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2007 US Open â Men's Singles">2007</a>) <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Roger Federer</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2008_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2008 US Open â Men's Singles">2008</a>) <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Roger Federer</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2009_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2009 US Open â Men's Singles">2009</a>) <a href="/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro" title="Juan MartÃ­n del Potro">Juan MartÃ­n del Potro</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2010_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2010 US Open â Men's Singles">2010</a>) <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2011_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2011 US Open â Men's Singles">2011</a>) <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2012 US Open â Men's Singles">2012</a>) <a href="/wiki/Andy_Murray" title="Andy Murray">Andy Murray</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2013_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2013 US Open â Men's Singles">2013</a>) <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2014_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2014 US Open â Men's Singles">2014</a>) <a href="/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87" title="Marin ÄiliÄ">Marin ÄiliÄ</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2015_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2015 US Open â Men's Singles">2015</a>) <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2016_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2016 US Open â Men's Singles">2016</a>) <a href="/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka" title="Stan Wawrinka">Stan Wawrinka</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2017_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2017 US Open â Men's Singles">2017</a>) <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2018_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2018 US Open â Men's Singles">2018</a>) <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a></li> 
                   <li>(<a href="/wiki/2019_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles" title="2019 US Open â Men's Singles">2019</a>) <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
              </tbody>
             </table>
            </div>

                           <li><span class="nowrap">1962: <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia"><img alt="Australia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Flag_of_Australia_%28converted%29.svg/18px-Flag_of_Australia_%28converted%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="18" height="9" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Flag_of_Australia_%28converted%29.svg/27px-Flag_of_Australia_%28converted%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Flag_of_Australia_%28converted%29.svg/36px-Flag_of_Australia_%28converted%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="640"></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a></span></li>

                     <div id="Non-calendar_year_Grand_Slam" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">
                      Non-calendar year Grand Slam
                     </div></th>

                    <td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0px">

                      <tbody>
                       <tr>
                        <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Men's singles</th>
                        <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                         <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                          <ul>
                           <li><span class="nowrap">2015â16: <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia"><img alt="Serbia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/18px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="18" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/27px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Flag_of_Serbia.svg/36px-Flag_of_Serbia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="945" data-file-height="630"></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a></span></li>
                          </ul> 
                         </div></td>
                       </tr>
                       <tr>
                        <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Women's singles</th>
                        <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                         <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                          <ul>

                        <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Women's singles</th>
                        <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

                         </div></td>
                       </tr>
